{{Infobox television | show_name = Aaj Robibar | image = File:Aaj Robibar cover.jpg | caption = DVD release cover | show_name_2 = | genre = [[Comedy]], [[Drama]] | creator = [[Humayun Ahmed]] | developer = | writer = [[Humayun Ahmed]] | director = Monir Hossain Jibon | creative_director = | presenter = | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Abul Hayat]] * [[Zahid Hasan]] * [[Suborna Mustafa]] * [[Aly Zaker]] * [[Meher Afroz Shaon|Shaon]] * [[Shila Ahmed]] }} | judges = | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = [[Maksud Jamil Mintu]] | opentheme = "Loke Bole" and "Nisha Lagilo Re"
by [[Hason Raja]] | endtheme = | composer = | country = [[Bangladesh]] | language = [[Bengali language|Bengali]] | num_seasons = | num_episodes = 7 | list_episodes = | executive_producer = | producer = | editor = Ahmed Shopon | location = Bangladesh Television Studios | cinematography = Mahmudur Rahman Sharif | camera = | runtime = Around 50 minutes | company = Nuhash Films | distributor = Nuhash Films | channel = [[Bangladesh Television|BTV]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = 1999 | last_aired = | status = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = | production_website = }} '''Aaj Robibar''' ({{lang-bn|আজ রবিবার}}; ''Today's Sunday'') is a Bangladeshi television [[sitcom]], created by [[Humayun Ahmed]], that was originally aired on [[Bangladesh Television|BTV]] in 1999. It was re-aired in Hindi on Indian television channel, [[Star Plus]] in 2017.{{cite news |last=Sagor |first=Faridur Reza |title=The Brilliance of Humayun Ahmed |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/the-brilliance-of-humayun-ahmed-44897 |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=15 August 2015}}{{cite news |last=Alom |first=Zahangir |title=Humayun Ahmed's musical creations under spotlight |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/humayun-ahmeds-musical-creations-under-spotlight-33754 |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=15 August 2015}} ==Plot== The plot revolves around the day-to-day life of an eccentric household consisting of a man only called ''Dadajan'' ("grandpa"), his socially in-adept sons, two granddaughters, a [[Boarding house|boarder]], the [[manservant]] and the maid. A drama about the daily comic incidents taking place in a Dhaka household, the series' opening episode begins with Konka, the younger granddaughter who [[breaking the fourth wall|breaks the fourth wall]] to introduce characters and premises to the audience. She and her elder sister Titli are fun-loving girls, both secretly in love with the boarder Anis, a [[nerd]] who doesn't seem to understand social stuff and never shows affection for any of them. Their father Jamil, the middle son and an architect by profession, is fond of Hason Raja songs and after losing his wife around the time when Konka was born, falls in love with an attractive, mature and intelligent woman named Meera, whom he hires as a governess. The eldest son, Asgor is an eminent psychiatrist and also falls in love with Meera. Meanwhile Farhad, who looks like "[[Baker Bhai|Baker vai]]" becomes involved with the family. Asgor, being convinced by Titli and Konka, hypnotizes Anis to induce the loving soul of him and changes him completely. Anis, then run after Titli and expresses his love for her, and seeks love in turn. In the end, Farhad goes outside with the younger brother of the house to see the miseries of the poor people of the street, and the younger brother says, he needs not to be [[Himu]] anymore if Farhad becomes Himu. ==Cast== * [[Abul Khair (actor)]] as Dadajan, head of the household * [[Abul Hayat]] as Jamil, Dadajan's middle son * [[Asaduzzaman Noor]] as Farhad * [[Zahid Hasan]] as Anis, the boarder * [[Suborna Mustafa]] as Meera, the governess * [[Aly Zaker]] as Asgor, the eldest son who is a psychiatrist * [[Meher Afroz Shaon|Shaon]] as Titli, the elder granddaughter * [[Shila Ahmed]] as Konka, Titli's younger sister * [[Faruk Ahmed (actor)|Faruk Ahmed]] as Moti, the manservant * [[Fazlul Kabir Tuhin]] as the youngest son, who thinks of himself as "[[Himu]]" (A fictional character of [[Humayun Ahmed]]) ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Bengal]] {{Bangladesh-tv-stub}}

The '''Aba''', who also call themselves the Aba Kizhi and a clan of the [[Shor people]] of [[Russia]]. They live along the [[Tom River]] in the general vicinity of [[Novokuznetsk]]. Although in the past they were at times considered a distinct people, they are now considered to be Shor. They are also called Abantsy, Aban, Abin and Abintsy.
==Sources== * Wixman, Ronald. ''The Peoples of the USSR: An Ethnographic Handbook''. (Armonk, New York: M. E. Sharpe, inc., 1984) p. 1
[[Category:Ethnic groups in Russia]]
{{Russia-stub}}

revision.text: {{Infobox airline | airline = AerianTur-M | image = | image_size = | alt = | IATA = | ICAO = | callsign = | founded = 1996 | commenced = | ceased = 2007 | aoc = | bases = *[[Chişinău International Airport]] | hubs = | secondary_hubs = | focus_cities = | frequent_flyer = | lounge = | alliance = | subsidiaries = | fleet_size = | destinations = | company_slogan = | parent = | headquarters = | key_people = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | profit = | assets = | equity = | website = }} '''AerianTur-M''' was an airline based in [[Chişinău]], [[Moldova]], which operated passenger and cargo charter services to the [[Middle East]] out of its base at [[Chişinău International Airport]].{{cite news | title= Directory: World Airlines | work= [[Flight International]] | page= 46 | date= 2007-03-27}} The company was founded in 1996 and ceased to exist in 2007.{{Cite web |url=http://www.airlineupdate.com/content_public/airlines/europe/moldova.htm |title=List of airlines from Moldova, at airlineupdate.com |access-date=2013-04-10 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120717011327/http://www.airlineupdate.com/content_public/airlines/europe/moldova.htm |archive-date=2012-07-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==Accidents and incidents== {{see also|2007 Balad aircraft crash}} *On January 9, 2007, 34 people were killed when an [[Antonov An-26]] airliner [[2007 Balad aircraft crash|crashed]] while attempting to land at [[Balad, Iraq|Balad]], [[Iraq]].{{cite news|first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Moldovan plane that crashed in Iraq was downed - eyewitness |url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20070112/58977626.htm |work= |publisher=Russian News and Information Agency Novosti |date= |accessdate=2007-01-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090817135427/http://en.rian.ru/world/20070112/58977626.htm |archivedate=2009-08-17 }} Officials say the accident was caused by fog, but witnesses and the [[Islamic Army in Iraq]] say it was shot down. ==Fleet== The AerianTur-M fleet included the following aircraft at March 2007: *1 [[Antonov An-12]] *2 [[Antonov An-26]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Airlines of Moldova}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aeriantur-M}} [[Category:Defunct airlines of Moldova]] [[Category:Airlines established in 1996]] [[Category:Airlines disestablished in 2007]] [[Category:Cargo airlines of Moldova]] {{Moldova-transport-stub}} {{Europe-airline-stub}}

MDN Investment (41%)
[[Albcontrol]] (10%) | traded_as = | ISIN = | headquarters = [[Tirana International Airport Nënë Tereza]], [[Rinas]], [[Albania]] | key_people = Sinan Dilek (CEO)
Sinan Idrizi
| revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | profit = | assets = | equity = | num_employees = | website = | notes = }} '''Air Albania''' is the national [[flag carrier]] [[airline]] of Albania,{{cite web |url=http://www.worldbulletin.net/headlines/205263/air-albania-to-launch-flights-in-september |title=Air Albania to launch flights in September |publisher=Worldbulletin News |date=24 August 2018 |access-date=24 August 2018 |language=English}}{{Cite web|url=http://top-channel.tv/2018/09/14/avioni-i-pare-i-air-albania-ulet-ne-rinas-rama-nisi-nje-epoke-e-re/ |title= Avioni i parë i “Air Albania” ulet në Rinas, Rama: Nisi një epokë e re |publisher=[[Top Channel]] |date=14 September 2018 |access-date=14 September 2018 |language=Albanian}} headquartered in [[Rinas]], [[Albania]]. The airline's [[airline hub|hub]] is at [[Tirana International Airport Nënë Tereza]], where the airline's corporate headquarters are also located. Air Albania was founded on 16 May 2018 by a consortium led by the Albanian and Turkish governments under a [[public–private partnership]]. [[Turkish Airlines]], a founding partner, owns 49.12% of Air Albania.{{cite web |url=https://exit.al/en/2018/08/03/air-albania-deal-also-violated-stabilization-and-association-agreement-with-eu/ |title=Air Albania Deal Also Violated Stabilization and Association Agreement with EU |publisher=Exit.al |date=8 August 2018 |access-date=26 August 2018 |language=English}} The remaining 50.88% is publicly traded, currently split between [[Albcontrol]], a corporation owned by the Albanian government, with roughly 10% and MDN Investment, a privately-held company in Albania, with roughly 41% of shares. ==History== Albania's previous national flag carrier airline, [[Albanian Airlines]] was rendered defunct when the Albanian government had revoked its license to operate in Albania on 11 November 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/airline-owned-by-suspected-mubarak-money-man-grounded|title=Albania to Ground Airline Owned by Arrested Businessman|publisher=Balkan Insight|date=14 November 2011|accessdate=15 September 2018}} Albanian Prime Minister [[Edi Rama]] had announced in an interview with Enver Robelli on 30 March 2017 that the Albanian government was planning to create an "airline in Albania with cooperation from Turkish Airlines and [[AtlasGlobal]]". On 8 May 2017, Rama and [[M. İlker Aycı|İlker Aycı]], executive director of Turkish Airlines, released a joint press statement, declaring that an Albania-based airline was in the works, with support from Turkish president [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]]. It was later revealed that Air Albania's foundation was also tied to the creation of an international airport in [[Vlorë]], also planned in cooperation with the Turkish government. Rama had unveiled the name of the new airline, Air Albania, on 21 November 2017.{{cite web |url=https://exit.al/en/2018/06/19/who-is-paying-for-air-albania-exit-explains/ |title=Who Is Paying for Air Albania? – Exit Explains |publisher=Exit.al |date=19 June 2018 |access-date=26 August 2018 |language=English}} Air Albania was officially founded on 16 May 2018 by Turkish Airlines, Albcontrol and MDN Investment. ===Controversy=== Controversy behind the airline's founding erupted when it was discovered that founding partner MDN Investment had been founded 9 days prior, on 7 May 2018. [[Turkish Airlines]] contributed 30 million dollars in their start-up.http://www.kokpit.aero/30-milyon-dolara-resmen-ortak Moreover, on 16 May 2018, the Albanian government had given control of the land on which the [[Tirana International Airport]] was built to [[Albcontrol]] in order to participate in the public-private partnership. Due to lack of public comment, Albania may have violated the [[Stabilisation and Association Process|Stabilisation and Association Agreement]] it had signed during its [[Accession of Albania to the European Union|accession process]] to the [[European Union]]. ==Destinations== The first flights of Air Albania will be first from Tirana to Istanbul. The airline will then expand its destinations to other countries in [[Europe]] and the [[United States]]. On 20 August 2018, it was confirmed that the first flight will depart in early September 2018. The first destination will be [[Istanbul]], operated by an [[Airbus A319]].{{cite web|url=https://americaneye.al/linja-e-pare-ajrore-shqiptare-rama-air-albania-nis-fluturimet-se-shpejti/|title=Air Albania nis fluturimet së shpejti|date=11 May 2018|language=Albanian}} As of September 2018 has planned flights to the following destination: {|class="sortable wikitable" |+ |- !City !Country !Airport !Notes |- |[[Tirana]]||[[Albania]]||[[Tirana International Airport Nënë Tereza]]||{{Airline hub}} |- |} ==Fleet== As of September 2018, the Air Albania fleet comprises the following aircraft:
{| class="wikitable" border="1" cellpadding="3" style="border-collapse:collapse; text-align:center" |+ '''Air Albania Fleet''' |- ! rowspan="2"|Aircraft ! rowspan="2"|In service ! rowspan="2"|Orders !colspan="3"|Passengers !rowspan="2" |Notes |- !C !Y !Total |- |[[Airbus A319-100]] |1 |— |— |160 | 160 | |- |[[Airbus A320-200]] |— |2 |colspan="3" | TBA |Order planned |- !Total !1 !2 !colspan="3"| ! |}
==See also== * [[List of airlines of Albania]] * [[List of defunct airlines of Albania]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portalbar|Albania|Companies|Aviation}} {{Airlines of Albania}} [[Category:Albanian brands]] [[Category:2018 establishments in Albania]] [[Category:Airlines established in 2018]] [[Category:Airlines of Albania]] {{Albania-stub}} {{Europe-airline-stub}}

page.title: An Historical Description of Three Kingdoms: Congo, Matamba, and Angola

revision.comment: http→https for [[Google Books]] and [[Google News]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Italic title}} '''''An Historical Description of Three Kingdoms: Congo, Matamba, and Angola''''' ([[Italian language|Italian]] ''Istorica descrizione de' tre' regni Congo, Matamba et Angola'') is an extensive work written by [[Giovanni Cavazzi da Montecuccolo|Giovanni Antonio Cavazzi da Montecuccolo]], an [[Italians|Italian]] [[Order of Friars Minor Capuchin|Capuchin]] [[missionary]], over a long period while working as a missionary in [[Angola]], between 1654 and 1677.
The work was commissioned by the [[Congregation for the Evangelization of Peoples|Holy Congregation for the Propagation of the Faith]] when Cavazzi returned from his first missionary trip to Angola in 1668. He completed a draft of the manuscript of the work around 1671, but opposition from the Church, primarily because of many miracle stories, which had fallen out of favor in the church, prevented its publication. After an interval, the task of editing the work was given to another Capuchin, Fortunato da Alamandini, who edited it, and it was eventually published in 1687 in [[Bologna]]. A second edition appeared in [[Milan]] in 1690
Cavazzi probably began writing this work around 1660, perhaps in response to his witnessing the conversion of [[Queen Nzinga|Queen Njinga]] to Christianity, which he regarded as something of a miracle.<ref>John Thornton, Introduction,[http://www.bu.edu/afam/faculty/john-thornton/cavazzi-missione-evangelica-2 Missione Evangelica] </ref> He wrote several drafts of a work which he called "Missione Evangelica" which he completed in 1668. This work, which is in the possession of the Araldi Family of [[Modena, Italy]], was published in English translation on the internet by John Thornton, with a full introduction, and a comparison between this early manuscript and that of the eventual book.<ref>John Thornton, [http://www.bu.edu/afam/faculty/john-thornton/cavazzi-missione-evangelica-2 Cavazzi Missione Evangelica]</ref>
==References==
Cavazzi da Montecuccolo, Giovanni Antonio (1687). [https://books.google.com/books?id=72j0A49gx0gC&printsec=frontcover&dq=giovanni+cavazzi+istorica+descrizione&hl=en&ei=ut6MTtzhE6Hf0QH6yaS1DA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CEIQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Istorica descrizione de tre regni Congo, Matamba ed Angola'']. Bologna: Giacomo Monti.
===Translations=== Labat, Jean-Baptiste (1732). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=mu0OAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false Relation historique de l'Ethiopie occidental]''. Paris: Delespine. 5 vols.
Saccardo, Graziano [da Luggazano] (1965) ed. and trans. ''Descrição histórica dos três reinos Congo, Angola e Matamba''. Lisbon: Agência Geral do Ultramar. 2 vols.
===Commentary=== Cuvelier, Jean (1949). "Notes sur Cavazzi," ''Zaire'' 3: 175-84.
Pistoni, Giuseppe (1969)"I manoscritti 'Araldi' di Padre Giovanni Antonio Cavazzi da Montecuccolo," ''Atti e memorie, Accademia di scienze, lettere e arti di Mondena'' 2: 152-65.
''idem''(1972). ''Fra Giovanni Antonio Cavazzi da Montecuccolo: Documenti inediti'' Modena
Thornton, John (1979). "New Light on Cavazzi's Seventeenth Century Description of Kongo," ''History in Africa'' 6: 253-64.
===Notes===
{{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:An Historical Description Of Three Kingdoms: Congo, Matamba, And Angola}} [[Category:African travel books]] [[Category:History of Africa]]

revision.text:
{{Citations|date=December 2014}} [[File:Title page of John's gospel from Oddur Gottskálksson's 1540 translation of the New Testament into Icelandic.jpg|thumb|Beginning of the Gospel of John from Oddur Gottskálksson's 1540 translation of the New Testament into Icelandic]] [[File:Gudbrandsbiblia.jpg|thumb|Title page of the elaborate printed bible of Guðbrandur Þorláksson, bishop, Hólar, 1584]] The New Testament was the first book printed in [[Icelandic language|Icelandic]]. It was translated by [[Oddur Gottskálksson]] (whose father was [[Norway|Norwegian]]) and published in 1540 (text here<ref>{{cite web|url=http://is.wikisource.org/wiki/N%C3%BDja_testamenti_Odds_Gottsk%C3%A1lkssonar|title=Nýja testamenti Odds Gottskálkssonar|publisher=Is.wikisource.org|accessdate=9 December 2014}}</ref>). Forty-four years later the whole Bible was printed in Icelandic thanks to [[Guðbrandur Þorláksson]], a Protestant [[bishop]] at [[Hólar]].
Afterwards, a number of other translations followed, such the ''Waysenhússbiblía'', a reworking of a 1644 Bible from Hólar and printed by G. F. Risel in Copenhagen. In 1813, in the same city, the [[British and Foreign Bible Society|British Bible Society]] published the ''Grútarbiblía'' (or ''Hendersonsbiblía''), just two years before the founding of the Icelandic Bible Society (Hið íslenzka Biblíufélag) by the British Bible Society's Ebenezer Henderson.
There came out a new translation in 1841, which was revised in 1863 by Professor (afterwards Bishop) Pétur Pétursson and Sigurður Melsteð, who compared it with the Greek and Hebrew originals and with the Norwegian, Danish, English and French versions. This edition (just the New Testament and Psalms) was edited by Eiríkr Magnusson and was reprinted in 1866, now as one volume with just the New Testament and Psalms and also another with the entire Old and New Testaments. Both the 1863 and 1866 editions were printed by the "Brit. Bible Soc." at [[Oxford University Press|Oxford]], and this seems to be the translation in the illustrated New Testament of the [[Scripture Gift Mission]] in 1903 ([[London]] & [[Akureyri]]). By at least 1906, the British Bible Society (now printing in [[Reykjavík]]) put out a new New Testament translation based on the original texts, by Haraldur Níelsson, and by 1908 released the entire Bible.
The current publisher of the Icelandic Bible is the Icelandic Bible Society. In 1859 they printed the so-called ''Reykjavíkurbiblía'', essentially the ''Viðeyjarbiblía'' from 18 years earlier. By at least 1899 they were printing the Old Testament translations of Þórir Þórðarson, which they used beyond the start of the 21st century. Their latest full translation, a new one by Guðrún Guðlaugsdóttir, was published in 2007.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! style="text-align:center; width:25%;"|Translation ![[Gospel of John|John]] 3:16 |- | style="text-align:center;"|''Hið Nýa Testament Jesu Christi'' (Oddur Gottskálksson, 1540) |Því að svo elskaði Guð heiminn að hann gaf út sinn eingetinn son til þess að allir þeir á hann trúa fyrirfærust eigi, heldur að þeir hafi eilíft líf. |- | style="text-align:center;"|''"Lundúnabiblían"'' (Pétur Pétursson and Sigurður Melsteð, 1863/1866) |Því svo elskaði Guð heiminn, að hann gaf sinn eingetinn Son, til þess að hver, sem á hann trúir, ekki glatist, heldur hafi eilift lif. |- | style="text-align:center;"|''Nýja Testamentið (Ný Þýðing)'' (Haraldur Níelsson, Brezka Biblíufélag, by 1906) |Því að svo elskaði Guð heiminn, að hann gaf son sinn eingetinn, til þess að hver sem á hann trúir glatist ekki, heldur hafi eilíft líf.
|}
==Further reading== *Guðbrandur Vigfússon and Frederick York Powell, ''Icelandic Prose Reader'' (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1874), [https://books.google.com/books?id=cKkDAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA433 pp. 433-443]. This section, "The Gospel of Matthew", is an extended discussion of the translations up until Guðbrand's and Powell's time.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.snerpa.is/net/biblia/biblia.htm The entire Bible] (minus Apocrypha; translation undetermined) from the Icelandic Biblíufélag. *The entire Bible [http://www.hljodbokasafn.is/hljodbaekur/opnar-baekur-fyrir-alla/ as audio-book] (''hljóðbók'') for free download. *[https://is.wikisource.org/wiki/N%C3%BDja_testamenti_Odds_Gottsk%C3%A1lkssonar Nýja testamenti Odds Gottskálkssonar]. *[https://www.biblegateway.com/versions/Icelandic-Bible/#vinfo Details of Icelandic versions]
[[Category:Bible translations by language|Icelandic]] [[Category:Icelandic language]]
{{Iceland-stub}} {{bible-translation-stub}}

[[File:Cornelis Boudewijns - detail of The Banquet of the Officers of the St George Militia Company in 1627 by Frans Hals.jpg|thumb|right|Cornelis Boudewijns, detail of Hals's banquet of 1627]] '''Cornelis Boudewijns van Lockhorst''' (c.1587 – 1635), was a [[Dutch Golden Age]] brewer of [[Haarlem]].
==Biography== He was the son of Boudewijn Willemsz., a Weesp magistrate and brewer in ''De Sleutel'' in [[Weesp]], and Hillegont Hendriksdr. van Bronckhorst. He was a brewer of the ''Twee Haringen'' and ''De Trompet'' in Haarlem. He married Aefje Willemsdr. the daughter of the brewers of the ''Twee Haringen'', Willem Gijsbrechtsz. and Guertje Dirks who outlived him and carried on the brewery.<ref name=RKD>[http://explore.rkd.nl/nl/images/11127 Cornelis Boudewijns] in record for this painting in the [[RKD]]</ref> He became a lieutenant of the St. George militia in Haarlem from 1624-1627 and from 1630-1633. He was portrayed by [[Frans Hals]] in ''[[The Banquet of the Officers of the St George Militia Company in 1627]]''.
On 7 March 1635 he was buried in Haarlem.<ref name=RKD/>
==References== {{reflist}} *[http://nha.courant.nu/issue/JJVH/1961-01-01/edition/null/page/52 Cornelis Boudewijns] in ''De Haarlemse Schuttersstukken'', by Jhr. Mr. C.C. van Valkenburg, pp. 50–51, Haerlem : jaarboek 1961, ISSN 0927-0728, on the website of the North Holland Archives
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Boudewijns, Cornelis}} [[Category:1587 births]] [[Category:1635 deaths]] [[Category:Frans Hals]] [[Category:People from Haarlem]]
{{Netherlands-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Crepulja''' is a shallow clay container with a little hole in the middle. It is put on fire until well heated, then lifted with a hook, and [[dough]] is put into it and covered with a [[sač]]. The sač is covered with ashes and live coals. In that way the [[bread]] is baked on both sides: on the lower side from the heated crepulja and on top from live coals.
==See also== * [[List of cooking vessels]]
[[Category:Cooking vessels]] [[Category:Montenegrin cuisine]] [[Category:Serbian cuisine]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Military Award |name=Cross of Merit |image=Kruis van Verdienste 1941.jpg |image_size=100px |caption=A Cross of Merit. There are several issues and types of this decoration. |awarded_by=[[Image:Flag of the Netherlands.svg|18px]] [[Kingdom of the Netherlands]] |type= [[Military award]] |eligibility= |for= Those working in the interest of the Netherlands while faced with enemy actions and distinguishing oneself through valor and resolute behavior |status=Currently awarded |description= |clasps= |established=20 February 1941 |first_award= |last_award= |total= 2,099 |posthumous= |recipients= |individual= |higher=[[Bronze Cross (Netherlands)|Bronze Cross]] |lower= [[Airman's Cross]] |image2=[[Image:Ribbon bar Dutch Cross of Merit.jpg|85px]] |caption2=Ribbon bar of the Cross of Merit }} On 20 February 1941, the Dutch government in exile in London instituted several new awards for bravery. The new way that wars were fought, with civilian resistance and the merchant navy in great peril, made this necessary. Amongst the new decorations was the "'''Cross of Merit'''", (Dutch: "Kruis van Verdienste") an award for "working in the interest of the Netherlands while faced with enemy actions and distinguishing oneself through valor and resolute behavior". One did not have to be on the front line to win this award. The cross has often been awarded to those who managed to flee to England and to the armed resistance. It was rarely awarded after the [[Korean War]], but since the [[Afghanistan_War_order_of_battle#Netherlands|fighting of the Netherlands army in Afghanistan]], [[Uruzgan]], this [[World War II]] decoration has been awarded again on a regular basis with the latest on 7 October 2009 to eleven Dutch soldiers. [http://www.defensie.nl/actueel/nieuws/2009/10/07/46136801/Dapperheidsonderscheidingen_voor_Afghanistangangers_video Bravery award for Afghanistan veterans] – Website [[Ministry of Defence (Netherlands)|Netherlands Ministry of Defence]] During the second world war in the Far East this cross was awarded to several people employed by the [[Koninklijke Paketvaart-Maatschappij]] (K.P.M.) as some of their merchant navy ships had been commissioned by the Dutch Navy during the [[Battle of the Java Sea]]. In case of repeated awards a large "2" or "3" is pinned to the ribbon. The Cross of Merit is the fourth-highest military decoration still being awarded for bravery and has precedence after the [[Bronze Cross (Netherlands)|Bronze Cross]]. ==References== {{reflist|1}} ==External links== * [http://lintjes.nl/onderscheidingen/andere-onderscheidingen/dapperheidsonderscheidingen The Cross of Merit] - Official site of the Chancellery of the Netherlands Orders (English) * {{nl icon}} [http://www.veteranen-online.nl/brons/verbrons.htm Vereniging DMD] - Website of the organization of veterans with the Cross of Merit
[[Category:Recipients of the Cross of Merit (Netherlands)| ]] [[Category:Military awards and decorations of the Netherlands|Merit, Cross]] [[Category:Awards established in 1941]] {{odm-stub}} {{Netherlands-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = HealthCare Volunteer | logo = | type = [[501(c)(3)]] | founded_date = December 27, 2005 | founder = [[Neilesh Patel]] DDS and Elliot Mendelsohn MD | President = Neilesh Patel | location = [[Los Angeles, California]] | office_locations = [[Liberia, Nigeria, Tanzania, India, Ecuador, Washington D.C. and Toronto]] | origins = | key_people = Neilesh Patel (President) Ravi Raghavan (Chief Operating Officer) Shahram Miri (General Counsel) | area_served = | focus = [[Healthcare]] | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = Over 150,000 website users | num_patients = Over 2 million served | num_employees = 58 volunteers/employees<ref name="about">{{Cite web|url=http://www.healthcarevolunteer.com/aboutus.php|title=About Us|accessdate=October 27, 2008|publisher=HealthCare Volunteer|year=2008|author=HealthCare Volunteer}}</ref> | num_members = Over 2+ million people served with 7.2 million volunteer hours | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = 'Empowering individuals to make an impact on global health' | homepage = http://www.healthcarevolunteer.com | tax_exempt = Yes | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
'''HealthCare Volunteer''' is a [[non-profit organization]] that connects volunteers with a health-related volunteering opportunity.<ref name="exam">{{Cite web|url=http://www.krnv.com/Global/story.asp?S=7061804&nav=menu113_5|title=Young Leader in United States Chosen to Receive a Global YouthActionNet Fellowship From the International Youth Foundation and Nokia|accessdate=November 11, 2007|publisher=WorldNow and KRNV|year=2007|author=PR Newswire|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929112901/http://www.krnv.com/Global/story.asp?S=7061804&nav=menu113_5|archivedate=September 29, 2011|df=}}</ref><ref name="npbio">{{Cite web|url=http://www.youthactionnet.org/yan_awards/awardwinner.cfm?awid=119|title=Neilesh Patel biography|accessdate=November 11, 2007|publisher=YouthActionNet|year=2007|author=YouthActionNet |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071011181129/http://youthactionnet.org/yan_awards/awardwinner.cfm?awid=119 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = October 11, 2007}}</ref> The organization provides medical, dental and surgical services to needy patients, and impoverished people worldwide, through indirect and direct patient-care programs.<ref name="mnt">{{Cite web|url=http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/61404.php|title=HealthCare Volunteer Launches Successful Health/nutrition Volunteering Pilot Program In Zimbabwe |accessdate=November 12, 2007|publisher=MediLexicon International Ltd|year=2007|author=Medical News Today}}</ref><ref name="ent">{{Cite web|url=http://www.entrepreneur27.org/archive/interview-with-neil-patel-of-healthcare-volunteer/|title=Interview with Neil Patel of HealthCare Volunteer|accessdate=November 12, 2007|publisher=Entrepreneur27.org|year=2007|author=Entrepreneur27.org|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026085431/http://www.entrepreneur27.org/archive/interview-with-neil-patel-of-healthcare-volunteer/|archivedate=October 26, 2007|df=}}</ref> The company also provides a social networking application, that allows health volunteers to connect with each other and create new volunteer teams. The organization has matched over 290,000 volunteers to nearly 3,300 organizations worldwide.<ref name="npbio" /> In total 1.5 million+ patients have received health care as a result of its indirect and direct patient care programs.
==History== In 2005, during his first year at UCLA Dental School, Patel decided to travel to Brazil to provide dental services to underserved communities. But he encountered difficulties in finding volunteer opportunities, having contacted more than 15 Brazilian organizations and receiving no response. He found that other dental and medical students had experienced similar problems. To address this problem, Patel created the Dental Volunteer and later HealthCare Volunteer to help connect students with volunteer opportunities.<ref name="Kivowitz">{{Cite web|url=http://newsroom.ucla.edu/portal/ucla/young-humanitarians-win-prestige-49332.aspx|title=Winners of the UCLA Humanitarian Awards|accessdate=April 28, 2008|publisher=UCLA Newsroom|year=2008|author=Elizabeth Kivowitz}}</ref> During Dental school, Neilesh Patel said he spent many "pizza nights" – subsisting on pizza and pulling all-nighters teaching himself how to program and build a Web site, which became the backbone of HealthCare Volunteer. He said he was driven by the belief that all qualified applicants should have the opportunity to volunteer. Soon now-orthopedic surgeon Elliot Mendelosohn, also a biomedical engineering major in his undergraduate days, joined Patel to help build HealthCare Volunteer.<ref name="DailyBruin">{{Cite web|url=http://dailybruin.com/news/2008/may/07/volunteers-awarded-humanitarian-efforts/|title=Neilesh Patel wins the UCLA Humanitarian Awards|accessdate=May 7, 2008|publisher=Daily Bruin UCLA Newsroom|year=2008|author=JJ Yang|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905001307/http://www.dailybruin.com/news/2008/may/07/volunteers-awarded-humanitarian-efforts/|archivedate=September 5, 2008|df=}}</ref>
Founded by [[Neilesh Patel|Neilesh Patel DDS]], and Elliot Mendelsohn MD in November, 2005, HealthCare Volunteer has a large listing of health-related volunteering opportunities serving the non-profit sector.<ref name="npbio" /> Volunteers include [[physician]]s, [[dentist]]s, [[medical student]]s, and [[dental assistant]]s, who donate their time to provide services including free surgery and dental care.<ref name="npbio" /> The organization has direct patient care programs in over 10 countries including India, Ecuador, Kenya, Tanzania, Liberia, Cameroon and Paraguay. In 2007, Patel was selected as a YouthActionNet Fellow in recognition of the organization's efforts, which was awarded at the Embassy of Finland in Washington DC.<ref name="ww">{{Cite web|url=http://press.nokia.com/PR/200708/1146865_5.html|title=International Youth Foundation and Nokia honor 20 global youth leaders as YouthActionNet(TM) Fellows|accessdate=November 12, 2007|publisher=[[Nokia]]|year=2007|author=[[Nokia]]}}</ref><ref name="yan">{{Cite web|url=http://www.youthactionnet.org/yan_awards/awardwinner.cfm|title=Winners of the YouthActionNet Awards, August 2007|accessdate=November 12, 2007|publisher=YouthActionNet|year=2007|author=YouthActionNet |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071011040145/http://www.youthactionnet.org/yan_awards/awardwinner.cfm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = October 11, 2007}}</ref> In 2008, Patel was awarded the UCLA Charles E Young Humanitarian Award for his work in global health. Patel reportedly dropped out of the UCLA MBA Program in 2007 after starting classes his first quarter as the first ever student in the integrated DDS/MBA program in order to focus on HV's growth.
Patel and Mendelsohn have also established HealthCare Tourism International, the first non profit medical [[tourism]] [[accreditation]] service.<ref name="hcfn">{{Cite web|url=http://www.healthcarefinancenews.com/story.cms?id=7040|title=First nonprofit medical tourism accreditation service launched|accessdate=November 12, 2007|publisher=Health Care Finance News|year=2007|author=Molly Merrill |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071105041343/http://www.healthcarefinancenews.com/story.cms?id=7040 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = November 5, 2007}} The organization has gained attention, and Patel was recently quoted in the New York Times on the subject of dental tourism.</ref> Patel started his first non-profit StudentsHelp.org (www.studentshelp.org) at age 17, which helped provide computer services and technical support to needy people around the world.
In 2013, Patel received the Samuel S. Beard Award for Greatest Public Service by an Individual 35 Years or Under, an award given out annually by [[Jefferson Awards for Public Service|Jefferson Awards]].<ref>http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/healthcare-volunteer-founder-neilesh-patel-named-national-jefferson-award-winner-in-washington-dc-212085991.html</ref>
==Volunteer networking== One of the unique features of the HealthCare Volunteer website is its ability to allow volunteers to create online profiles and connect with other volunteers. Once volunteers have signed up and created their profiles, they can form volunteering teams for service at home or abroad.
==Exercising a 'free volunteering' philosophy== HealthCare Volunteer has sought to reduce the financial burdens for both volunteers and organizations. First, volunteers pay no money to search HealthCare Volunteer for volunteering opportunities nor must organizations pay any money to post their volunteering opportunities on HealthCare Volunteer. Secondly, HealthCare Volunteer strives to exclusively partner with organizations that do not charge their volunteers additional money beyond accommodation and other essential services in order to volunteer. HealthCare Volunteer believes that volunteers are already volunteering their time and effort and should not be required to pay additional fees above the basic costs (travel, accommodation, and basic services).<ref name="Partner Policy">{{Cite web|url=http://healthcarevolunteer.com/organizations/partnerpolicy.php?PHPSESSID=b61fd64e534e41faf8df1a66e7e15c0f|title=HealthCare Volunteer Partner Philosophy|accessdate=September 10, 2007|publisher=HealthCare Volunteer|year=2007|author=Ravi Raghavan}}</ref>
==Organizational awards== In 2007, HealthCare Volunteer began awarding volunteers who helped advance the mission of HealthCare Volunteer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://healthcarevolunteer.com/news/12262007.php|title=HealthCare Volunteer 2007 Awards|accessdate=December 26, 2007|publisher=HealthCare Volunteer|year=2007|author=Manjusha Dutta}}</ref>
'''2007 Awards:'''
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Award ! Recipient ! Comments |- | Leadership | Ravi Raghavan | For fundraising, recruiting, public relations, and new partnerships |- | Medical Field Excellence | Dr. Samuel Feinstein | For surgery work in Tanzania |- | Dental Field Excellence | Dr. Jason Ehtessabian | For dental work in Tanzania |- | Innovation Award | Dr. Tara Athan, PhD | For world's first health-related NGO and volunteer interactive, online map |- | Opportunity Expansion Award | Erick Mlanga | For creating volunteering opportunities in Tanzania |- | Organizational Award | Carolina Myans | For uploading new volunteering opportunities onto HealthCare Volunteer's website |- | Student Volunteer Award | Colin Casault | For overcoming numerous obstacles to perform volunteer work in rural Tanzania |}
'''2008 Awards:'''
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Award ! Recipient ! Comments |- | Leadership | Ravi Raghavan | This year, Mr. Raghavan launched the India chapter of HealthCare Volunteer and recruited new volunteers from India. |- | Medical Field Excellence | Dr. Seth Podolsky | For public health medical work in Galapagos Islands |- | Dental Field Excellence | Andi Michels | For dental work in Tanzania |- | Innovation Award | Adil Shafique | For world's first health-related NGO and volunteer interactive, online map |- | Opportunity Expansion Award | Catherine Matthys | For creating volunteering opportunities in Tanzania |- | Student Volunteer Award | Sarah Richardson | For overcoming numerous obstacles to perform volunteer work in rural Tanzania |}
==See also== *[[List of volunteer awards|List of awards for volunteerism and community service]]
==References== *[https://translate.google.com/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=auto&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fderstandard.at%2F1282979371030%2FAuslandsbehandlung-Gute-Reise-in-die-Besserung HealthCare Volunteer acquires HealthCare Tourism International]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.healthcarevolunteer.com HealthCare Volunteer website] *[http://www.dentalvolunteer.com Dental Volunteer website] *[http://travel.nytimes.com/2008/02/07/fashion/07SKIN.html?scp=1&sq=neil+patel&st=nyt New York Times mention] *[http://www.shreveporttimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080303/LIVING02/803010311/1004/LIVING Shreveport Times mention] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MBEKDsVkV9I KTLA - Los Angeles Story] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vfgKo3SLW5Y TV interview with Company's Founder] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U408QtDRGk0&feature=related Documentary with Company's Founder with Starbucks Coffee Foundation] *[http://www.brain-storming.info/article.php?ida=89 Brainstorming Interview with Company's Founder] *[http://www.apathyisboring.com/en/the_facts/news/1073 Company's Founder mentioned in the Financial Times] *[http://www.newsroom.ucla.edu/portal/ucla/young-humanitarians-win-prestige-49332.aspx Company's Founder, Neilesh Patel, awarded Humanitarian Award] *[http://spotlight.ucla.edu/students/humanitarian-award-2008/ Company's Founder mentioned by UCLA Newsroom]

revision.text:
{{Use American English|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = Intelsat 804 | image = | image_caption = | mission_type = [[Communications satellite|Communications]] | operator = [[Intelsat]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = 1997-083A | SATCAT = 25110 | mission_duration = 14 years (planned) | spacecraft_bus = | spacecraft_type = [[Spacebus|AS-7000]] | manufacturer = [[Lockheed Martin]] | dry_mass = | BOL_mass = | launch_mass = {{convert|3412|kg|lb}} | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|December 22, 1997, 00:16|timezone=yes}} UTC{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|work=Jonathan's Space Page|accessdate=May 5, 2017}} | launch_rocket = [[Ariane 4|Ariane-42L H10-3]] | launch_site = [[Guiana Space Centre|Kourou]] [[ELA-2]] | launch_contractor = [[Arianespace]] | disposal_type = | deactivated = {{end-date|January 14, 2005, 22:32}} UTC | orbit_epoch = May 5, 2017{{cite web|url=http://www.n2yo.com/satellite/?s=25110|title=INTELSAT 804 |work=N2YO|accessdate=May 5, 2017}} | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[geostationary orbit|Geostationary]]
Now [[supersynchronous orbit|supersynchronous]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|35,776.2|km|mi}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|35,820.4|km|mi}} | orbit_inclination = 9.7 degrees | orbit_semimajor = {{convert|42,169.0|km|mi}} | orbit_period = 1,436.3 minutes | orbit_longitude = 44° E | apsis = gee | trans_band = 38 [[C band (IEEE)|C Band]], 6 [[Ku band]] | trans_frequency = | trans_bandwidth = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = [[Indian Ocean]] | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = ''Intelsat 8'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat 803]] | next_mission = [[Intelsat 805]] }} '''Intelsat 804''' was a [[communications satellite]] operated by [[Intelsat]]. Launched in 1997 it was operated in [[geostationary orbit]] at a longitude of 44 degrees east for around 8 years. ==Satellite== The fourth of six [[Intelsat VIII]] satellites to be launched, Intelsat 804 was built by [[Lockheed Martin]]. It was a {{convert|3412|kg|lb|adj=on}} spacecraft. The satellite carried a 2x[[LEROS-1B]] [[apogee motor]] for propulsion and was equipped with 38 [[C band (IEEE)|C Band]] [[transponder]]s and 6 [[Ku band]] [[transponder]]s, powered by 2 solar cells more batteries.{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/intlsat.htm|title=Intelsat|first=Mark|last=Wade|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica|accessdate=May 5, 2017}} It was designed for a fourteen-year service life.{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/intelsat-8.htm|title=Intelsat-8 (801, 802, 803, 804) / NSS 803 → NSS 5|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=May 5, 2017}} ==Launch== The launch of Intelsat 804 made use of a [[Ariane 4]] rocket flying from [[Guiana Space Centre]], [[Kourou]], [[French Guiana]]. The launch took place at 00:116 UTC on December22, 1997, with the spacecraft entering a [[geosynchronous transfer orbit]]. The satellite subsequently fired its apogee motor to achieve [[geostationary orbit]]. ==Failure== On 14 January 2005 at 22:32 UTC, there was a failure of the power system.[https://www.tbs-satellite.com/tse/online/sat_intelsat_804.html TSE-Intelsat 804]. Retrieved 2017-5-05. ==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [[1997 in spaceflight]] {{Clear}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Intelsat}} {{Orbital launches in 1997}} [[Category:Intelsat satellites]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1997]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Portugal}} "Menina do alto da serra" | image = | caption = | year = 1971 | country = Portugal | artist = Tonicha | as = | with = | language = Portuguese | languages = | composer = Nuno Nazareth Fernandes | lyricist = [[Ary dos Santos]] | conductor = Jorge Costa Pinto | place = 9th | points = 83 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1971pt from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Desfolhada portuguesa | prev_year = 1969 | prev_link = Desfolhada portuguesa | next = A festa da vida | next_link = A festa da vida }} '''Menina do alto da serra''' ("High ridge girl"), also known in [[Portugal]] just as '''Menina''' and for this reason sometimes entitled '''Menina (do alto da serra)''', was the [[Portugal|Portuguese]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1971]], performed in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] by [[Tonicha]].
The song is a ballad, with Tonicha describing a simple country girl. She presents the girl as an ideal to which everyone should aspire in their lives.
The song was performed fifteenth on the night, following the [[Netherlands]]' [[Saskia & Serge]] with "[[Tijd]]" and preceding [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]]'s [[Kruno Slabinac]] with "[[Tvoj dječak je tužan]]". At the close of voting, it had received 83 points, placing 9th (at the time the best Portuguese result) in a field of 18.
It was succeeded as [[Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest|Portuguese representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1972|1972 contest]] by [[Carlos Mendes (singer)|Carlos Mendes]] with "[[A festa da vida]]".
{{Eurovision Song Contest 1971}} {{Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest}}
[[Category:Eurovision songs of Portugal]] [[Category:Portuguese-language songs]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1971]] [[Category:Songs with lyrics by Ary dos Santos]]
{{portugal-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Arab Republic of Egypt
Ministry of Local Development |nativename = وزارة الدولة للتنمية المحلية |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo =Coat of arms of Egypt (Official).svg |logo_width =150px |logo_caption =[[Emblem of Egypt]] |jurisdiction = {{flagicon|Egypt}} [[Egypt]] |headquarters = [[Giza]]{{cite web |title=Contact Us |url=http://mld.gov.eg/en/contact-us |website=Ministry of Local Development}} |coordinates = |chief1_name = [[Mahmoud Youssry Shaarawy]] |chief1_position = Minister |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |chief3_name = |chief3_position = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = http://mld.gov.eg }} The '''Ministry of Local Development''' is the Egyptian government body responsible for local development. It is currently headed by [[Mahmoud Youssry Shaarawy]].{{Cite web|url=http://egypt.gov.eg/english/guide/directory.aspx|title=Egypt’s Government Services Portal - Ministries Directory and Sites|website=egypt.gov.eg|access-date=2018-10-15}} The ministry was established by the decision of the [[President of Egypt]] with decree No. 325 of 1999. One of its objectives is to coordinate various efforts for the development of local communities and administration units in partnership with the [[governorates of Egypt]].{{cite web|url=http://mld.gov.eg/en/p/3/about-us/|title=ABOUT THE MINISTRY|work=mld.gov.eg|accessdate=15 October 2018}} ==Initiatives== The ministry's goals are to decentralize power and to provide employment for youth and women especially.{{cite web |title=Home |url=http://mld.gov.eg/?lang=en |website=Ministry of Local Development}} Their projects include decreasing illiteracy in Egypt, improving public services, generating more civic engagement, preparing local leaders, and in unison with other ministries, providing the land for the building of new housing units.{{cite web |title=Projects |url=http://mld.gov.eg/en/projects?page=2 |website=Ministry of Local Development}} In 2018, the ministry requested that restrictions on [[Tuk Tuk]] licensing be lifted in order to ease congestion in cities.{{cite news |last1=Hisham |first1=Shahd |title=Egypt's local development minister calls for lifting restrictions on tuk tuk licensing |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/310294/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-local-development-minister-calls-for-liftin.aspx |work=Ahram Online |date=26 August 2018}} ==See also== {{Portal|Egypt}} * [[Cabinet of Egypt]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://egypt.gov.eg/english/guide/directory.aspx Egypt's Cabinet Database] * [http://mld.gov.eg/?lang=en Ministry of Local Development Official Site in English ] {{Egyptian ministries}} [[Category:Government ministries of Egypt]] {{egypt-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Union |name= Norwegian Transport Workers’ Union
Norsk Transportarbeiderforbund |country= [[Norway]] |affiliation= [[Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions|LO]], [[International Transport Workers' Federation|ITF]] |members= 20,000+ |full_name= Norwegian Transport Workers' Union |native_name= Norsk Transportarbeiderforbund, NTF |image= [[File:Transportarbeider logo.jpg|200px]] |founded= 1896 |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= [[Oslo]], [[Norway]] |people= Roger Hansen, president |website= [http://www.transportarbeider.no/ www.transportarbeider.no] |footnotes= }} '''Norwegian Transport Workers' Union''' ([[Norwegian language|Norwegian]]:''Norsk Transportarbeiderforbund'', NTF) is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[trade union]] which was established on 2 April 1896. The union organizes workers in [[logistics]] and private goods and passenger transport. The main areas for the union are drivers plus workshop and maintenance personnel in the [[bus]] companies, warehouses and terminal workers, drivers in forwarding and wholesale industry, [[mailroom]] employees and delivering personnel in newspaper companies, [[taxi driver]]s, employees in the environmental industry (waste disposal and recycling), [[freight]] drivers (long and local transport of goods ) and [[stevedores]] workers in the [[port]]s. The union has over 20,000 members in 20 unions across Norway. The union's head office in Oslo consists of eight officers and nine employees. NTF joined the [[Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions]] (LO) in 1907 and is a member of the [[International Transport Workers' Federation]]. The unions' leader is Roger Hansen. ==References== {{Reflist}} *{{cite book| year = 2005| title = Trade Unions of the World| editor = [[International Centre for Trade Union Rights|ICTUR]] et al.,| edition = 6th| publisher = John Harper Publishing| location = London, UK| isbn = 0-9543811-5-7}} == External links == [http://www.transportarbeider.no/kunder/ntf/cms.nsf/pages/english NTF website in '''English'''] {{Portal|Organised labour}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Norwegian Transport Workers' Union}} [[Category:International Transport Workers' Federation]] [[Category:Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions]] [[Category:Trade unions established in 1896]] {{Norway-org-stub}} {{Europe-trade-union-stub}}

Gerard Alfons Kusz |website = [http://www.kuria.gliwice.pl/ Diocese of Gliwice] }} The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Gliwice''' ({{lang-la|Glivicen(sis)}}) is an [[diocese]] located in the city of [[Gliwice]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Katowice|Katowice]] in [[Poland]]. About 91% of the population is Roman Catholic, however only 39% are practising Catholics (as of October 2013). ==History== * March 25, 1992: Established as Diocese of Gliwice from the [[Diocese of Częstochowa]], Diocese of Katowice and [[Diocese of Opole]] ==Leadership== * [[Bishop]]s of Gliwice (Roman rite) ** Bishop [[Jan Walenty Wieczorek]] (March 25, 1992 – December 29, 2011) ** Bishop [[Jan Kopiec]] (since December 29, 2011) * [[Auxiliary bishop]]s of Gliwice (Roman rite) ** Bishop [[Gerard Kusz]] (March 25, 1992 – November 15, 2014)http://kuria.gliwice.pl/diecezja/biskupi/gerard-kusz-senior/ ** Bishop [[Andrzej Iwanecki]] (since January 7, 2018)http://kuria.gliwice.pl/diecezja/biskupi/andrzej-iwanecki/ ==See also== *[[Roman Catholicism in Poland]] ==Sources== * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/gliw0.htm GCatholic.org] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dgliw.html Catholic Hierarchy] * [http://www.kuria.gliwice.pl/ Diocese website] ==References== {{Roman Catholic dioceses in Poland}} {{coord|50.2913|N|18.6655|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gliwice}} [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Poland]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1992]] [[Category:Gliwice]] [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses and prelatures established in the 20th century]] {{Poland-stub}} {{Europe-RC-diocese-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:Wahlkreise Caprivi.png|thumb|Zambezi Region Constituencies
4 = Sibbinda]] '''Sibbinda Constituency''', also: '''Sibinda Constituency''', is an [[electoral constituency]] in the [[Zambezi Region]] of [[Namibia]]. It is situated in the [[Caprivi Strip]] and is regularly affected by floods of the [[Zambezi River]]. The district capital is the village of [[Sibbinda]]. The constituency's population is 9,164.{{cite news |url=http://www.namibian.com.na/indexx.php?archive_id=24828&page_type=archive_story_detail&page=4790 |title=Sibinda flood victims evacuated |last=Dentlinger |first=Lindsay |date=3 March 2006 |work=[[The Namibian]]}} ==Politics== The councillor is [[Ignatius Chunga]] of [[South West Africa People's Organization|SWAPO Party]] who won a 2012 constituency by-election that was scheduled after the previous councillor [[Felix Mukupe]] died in a car accident.{{cite news |url=http://www.namibian.com.na/indexx.php?archive_id=100026&page_type=archive_story_detail&page=699 |title=Swapo wins Sibbinda |last=Poolman |first=Jan |date=17 September 2012 |work=[[The Namibian]]}} Chunga was reelected in the [[Namibian local and regional elections, 2015|2015 regional election]] with 1,924 votes, followed by Luseso Parry Malumbano of the [[Democratic Turnhalle Alliance]] (DTA) with 322 votes and of the Lister Limbo Sabuta [[Rally for Democracy and Progress (Namibia)|Rally for Democracy and Progress]] (RDP) with 314 votes.{{Cite web | title=Regional Council Election Results 2015 | publisher=[[Electoral Commission of Namibia]] | date=3 December 2015 | page=23 | url=http://www.ecn.na/documents/27857/223442/Regional+Counils+Election+Results_Duly+elected+candidates+2015.pdf/32493774-80b3-4be3-9ca1-1f6ce187673a?version=1.0 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208163948/http://www.ecn.na/documents/27857/223442/Regional+Counils+Election+Results_Duly+elected+candidates+2015.pdf/32493774-80b3-4be3-9ca1-1f6ce187673a?version=1.0 | archivedate=8 December 2015 | df= }} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Constituencies of the Zambezi Region}} {{coord|17|47|S|23|49|E|type:adm2nd_source:kolossus-itwiki|display=title}} [[Category:Constituencies of Zambezi Region]] {{Namibia-gov-stub}}

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Sweetsalt | image = | landscape = | caption = | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[Lithuania]] | genre = [[Rock music|Rock]], [[Alternative rock|Alternative]] | years_active = {{start date|2006}}–present | label = | associated_acts = | website = http://www.sweetsalt.lt/ | current_members = Rokas Dobužinskas
Romanas Dzindzeleta
Vytautas Vansavičius
Mindaugas Stundžia | past_members = Pijus Ganauskas
Šarūnas Dirsė
Jurgis Cicėnas }} '''Sweetsalt''' is a [[Lithuania]]n [[Rock music|rock]] band formed in 2006 by lead vocalist Rokas Dobužinskas and lead guitarist Pijus Ganauskas.{{cite news|title="Sweetsalt" muzika gimsta vištidėje|url=http://gatve.delfi.lt/news/veidai/sweetsalt-muzika-gimsta-vistideje.d?id=21344581|accessdate=28 October 2013|newspaper=DELFI gatvė|date=6 April 2009}} Soon after bassist Šarūnas Dirsė and drummer Jurgis Cicėnas joined, completing the line-up. The band quickly rose to fame, especially after winning Coca-Cola Soundwave contest in 2008, receiving a chance to perform in [[Coke Live Music Festival]] along with [[The Prodigy]] and [[Timbaland]]. The same year they also closed one of the biggest baltic music festivals [[Be2gether]].{{cite web|title=Sweetsalt Biografija|url=http://www.sweetsalt.lt/lt/biografija/|accessdate=28 October 2013}} In 2009, Sweetsalt performed in various rock concerts and night clubs. However the band didn't show up in any major events and was quickly forgotten by the media. In 2010 the band reformed with the current composition and released their debut album ''Jie man sakė (They told me)'' in 2011.{{cite news|title=Debiutinis Sweetsalt albumas "Jie man sakė" – netikėta šviesa tunelio gale|url=http://sharkeen.lt/2011/02/05/debiutinis-sweetsalt-albumas-jie-man-sake-netiketa-sviesa-tunelio-gale/|accessdate=28 October 2013|date=5 February 2011}} == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Lithuanian rock music groups]] {{Europe-band-stub}} {{Lithuania-stub}}

postal_code_type = | postal_code = | timezone1 = [[Time in Australia|AEST]] | utc_offset1 = +10 | website = | blank_name_sec1 = Location | blank_info_sec1 = * {{convert|12|km|abbr=on}} from [[Ok Tedi mine]] * {{convert|94|km|abbr=on}} from [[Kiunga, Papua New Guinea|Kiunga]] * {{convert|310|km|abbr=on}} from [[Jayapura]] * {{convert|807|km|abbr=on}} from [[Port Moresby]] * {{convert|1776|km|abbr=on}} from [[Dili]] | blank_name = Mean max temp | blank_info = {{convert|29|C|F}} | blank1_name = Mean min temp | blank1_info = {{convert|20|C|F}} | blank2_name = Annual rainfall | blank2_info = {{convert|8000|mm|in|sigfig=4|abbr=on}} | blank3_name = [[Köppen climate classification|Climate]] | blank3_info = [[Tropical rainforest climate|Af]] }} '''Tabubil''' is a planned, company operated township located in the [[Star Mountains]] area of the [[North Fly District, Western Province|North Fly District]] of [[Western Province, Papua New Guinea|Western Province]], [[Papua New Guinea]].<ref name=QuickFacts>{{cite web | url = http://tourism_northfly.byethost18.com/quickfacts.htm | title = Quick Facts | publisher = North Fly District Tourism | year = 2007}}</ref> The town, including the adjoining relocated village of Wangabin and the industrial area of Laydown (where industrial equipment was originally laid down before being installed at the mine ~1970–1980), is the largest settlement in the province,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.oktedi.com/community/townships.php | title = Townships | publisher = Ok Tedi Mining Limited | year = 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070403171854/http://www.oktedi.com/community/townships.php | archivedate = 2007-04-03 | df = }}</ref> although the provincial capital, [[Daru]] is a similar size.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.pngbd.com/travel/tourism_guide_tpa/index.php | title = Population by Statistical LLG Areas (Western Province) | publisher = Papua New Guinea Business and Tourism | year = 2002}}</ref> It had a recorded population of 10,270 at the 2011 census.<ref name=nso2 />
Tabubil is set in extremely dense jungle fed by one of the highest rainfalls in the world. The town is the largest settlement in the country that has [[List of towns and cities in Papua New Guinea by population|never been a provincial capital, or incorporated within one]]. The town was established primarily to serve the [[Mining|mine]] of [[Ok Tedi mine|Ok Tedi]], which is currently mining [[copper]] and [[gold]].
== History ==
=== Pre colonisation === Tabubil lies in the heart of the Min Nation, an area with a distinct ethnic makeup that straddles the [[Indonesia]]n border, and extends towards the southern [[Sepik]] areas and throughout the northern [[Fly River]] system.<ref name="Brown, 1978">{{cite book|last=Brown|first=Paula|title=Highland Peoples of New Guinea|year=1978|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge, UK|isbn=9780521292498|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PwQ4AAAAIAAJ&dq=highland+people+of+papua+new+guinea&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref> During the early years of colonisation of [[New Guinea]] it was unknown how many people, if any, lived in this remote and seemingly impassable and inhospitable terrain.{{Citation needed|date=October 2007}}
Before the 1940s, outside contact with the [[Mountain Ok people|Min people]] was either brief, or merely vicarious.<ref name=minemerge>{{cite news|title=Regional history and ethnic identity in the hub of New Guinea: The emergence of the Min |author="Jorgensen, Dan"|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3654/is_199603/ai_n8738925/print }} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> It is thought the Min were pushed north hundreds or even thousands of years ago by war with the southern [[Gogodala people]]s, who were a strong warrior nation that currently reside on the plains of the [[Middle Fly District, Western Province|central Fly area]] of the Western Province.{{By whom|date=January 2010}}
=== Colonisation of Telefomin === {{Main article|Telefomin}} It was not until 1943 that [[USAAF]] gliders landed deep in the [[Star Mountains]] to establish an airstrip station in what is now [[Telefomin]], about 25 km north-east of Tabubil. This is the first permanent colonial influence on the Min people, who at the time were [[Cannibal]]s involved in a deep tribal war. Soon after the arrival of the Americans, the [[Telefolmin tribe]] experienced a [[cessation of hostilities]] with its neighbours, the [[Falamin]] and the [[Tifalmin]] due to mutually agreeable conditions that emerged from the construction and introduction of western goods and services. Conflict between social groups was also forcefully deterred by Australian colonial administrators. After colonial pacification, trade flourished in the area.<ref name=minemerge/><ref>{{Citation | last =Jorgensen | first =Dan | year =2006 | title =Hinterland History: The Ok Tedi Mine and Its Cultural Consequences in Telefolmin | publisher =The Contemporary Pacific 18(2) }}</ref>
=== Mining town === [[Image:Tabubil-world wind.png|thumb|270px|NASA [[Landsat]] image of Tabubil with a North-West perspective and [[Ok Tedi Mine]] in the background.]]
Tabubil, originally a small camp surrounding an airstrip, was set up as a base of operations for drilling sites by the [[Kennecott Copper Corporation]]. In 1976, [[Australia]]n mining company [[BHP Billiton|BHP]] entered into negotiations with the Papua New Guinea government in an attempt to gain control of the camp and establish it as a gold mining town.<ref name=OTMLHistory>{{cite web | url = http://www.oktedi.com/aboutus/history.php | title = History of Development | publisher = Ok Tedi Mining Limited | year = 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071022020110/http://www.oktedi.com/aboutus/history.php | archivedate = 2007-10-22 | df = }}</ref> BHP was successful in 1980, and in 1981, [[Ok Tedi Mining Limited]] was established to take control of operations, with a major BHP shareholding.<ref name=OTMLHistory/>
Today, the old Kennecott camp is still standing. {{Citation needed|date=July 2014}} Known locally as the "A" houses, they are [[ATCO]] shipping crate styled houses. Later, the "B" and "C" houses were built by BHP for their workers. BHP has built the majority of the town, with structures placed by other companies and the national government making up only a small percentage of the total buildings. {{Citation needed|date=July 2014}}
== Culture == Tabubil is host to a diverse range of cultures, due to its workforce historically being sourced from many parts of PNG, Australia, Asia, Europe and the Americas. Most expatriates are Australian, but there are also many Filipinos. A [[Canada|Canadian]] mining company, [[Inmet Mining|Inmet Mining Corporation]] owns an 18% stake in the mine,<ref name=KeyStats/> and of Tabubil.  A number of Canadians, particularly those from [[Port Hardy]] on [[Vancouver Island]], have also resided in Tabubil. During recent years, however, Ok Tedi Mining Limited has looked closer to home for human resources, with its long existent, but recently enforced ''preferred area'' human resourcing plan.
=== Events === The main cultural event of the year is Papua New Guinea's Independence Day. The event is proceeded by a festival known as the "Amamas Week" meaning joyful week, encompassing a week of traditional and contemporary dancing(arranged and performed by school students, local groups and groups from other provinces), music, traditional ceremonies. In the 90s, performers from other countries like Samoa, New Zealand, were also invited to showcase their traditional dances for that joyful week. {{Citation needed|date=July 2014}}
An election is extremely important to local residents, often inciting riots, tribal conflict, and other forms of [[civil disobedience]]. The provincial government has banned the sale of alcohol during an election to try and curb violence. {{Citation needed|date=July 2014}}
[[Melbourne Cup]] day has been a well celebrated event since the foundation of the town. As many expatriate residents of the town are from Australia, Melbourne Cup celebrations have been a traditionally important connection to the culture left behind in Australia. {{Citation needed|date=July 2014}}
=== Religion === The most popular religion in the town is Christianity.<ref>{{Citation | last =MacDonald | first =Mary | year =2005 | title =Becoming Sinners: Christianity and Moral Torment in a Papua New Guinea Society | publisher =The Contemporary Pacific }}</ref> There are still a few people that hold traditional beliefs, and others that blend traditional beliefs with Christianity.<ref>{{Citation | last =Jorgensen | first =Dan | year =2005 | title =Third Wave Evangelism and the Politics of the Global in Papua New Guinea: Spiritual Warfare and the Recreation of Place in Telefolmin | publisher =Oceania 75(4) }}</ref>
Tabubil is host to four major permanent churches, and many other church groups that meet in the large undercover areas beneath the "B" and "C" style houses.
The [[Mission Aviation Fellowship]] has a presence in [[Tabubil Airport]] and the [[YMCA]] and [[YWCA]] hold a strong influence over the town culture and commerce.
=== Media === Although many people in Tabubil own computers, Internet use is very rare. There is, however, a wide selection of cable TV stations available from Singapore, Australia, Indonesia, Malaysia, PNG, and the USA. There is a local TV station called OTV. Several AM and FM radio stations are available in town. Radio Fly on Shortwave 3915 kHz and 5960 kHz.
Mobile (Cellular) phone and data services are provided by Telikom PNG (CitiFon) <ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.telikompng.com.pg/index.php/citifon/network-coverage |title=Archived copy |access-date=2017-01-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202123824/http://www.telikompng.com.pg/index.php/citifon/network-coverage |archive-date=2017-02-02 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> and Digicel.<ref>https://www.telcoantennas.com.au/site/digicel-papua-new-guinea-coverage-map</ref>
== Climate == Tabubil has a [[tropical rainforest climate]]. The town is known unofficially as one of the wettest places on earth, with an average annual rainfall of 8 metres per annum, and a peak rainfall of 10 metres per annum.<ref name=QuickFacts/> The unique weather conditions have caused much adaptation in the local jungle flora and fauna, causing Tabubil to be particularly interesting to the scientific community.
Tabubil often has a transient population that aren't used to the large amounts of rain that fall there. Locals, however, operate quite happily in the rain, as it rains daily, and residents cannot afford to let it disrupt their lives.
{{Weather box |location = Tabubil |metric first = Y |single line = Y |Jan high C = 30 |Feb high C = 30 |Mar high C = 31 |Apr high C = 31 |May high C = 31 |Jun high C = 31 |Jul high C = 30 |Aug high C = 30 |Sep high C = 30 |Oct high C = 30 |Nov high C = 30 |Dec high C = 30 |year high C = |Jan low C = 17 |Feb low C = 17 |Mar low C = 17 |Apr low C = 17 |May low C = 17 |Jun low C = 17 |Jul low C = 16 |Aug low C = 16 |Sep low C = 16 |Oct low C = 17 |Nov low C = 17 |Dec low C = 17 |year low C = |Jan rain mm = 644 |Feb rain mm = 601 |Mar rain mm = 672 |Apr rain mm = 595 |May rain mm = 593 |Jun rain mm = 648 |Jul rain mm = 565 |Aug rain mm = 584 |Sep rain mm = 520 |Oct rain mm = 505 |Nov rain mm = 459 |Dec rain mm = 572 |year rain mm = 6958 |source = http://www.worldclimateguide.co.uk/climateguides/papuanewguinea/tabubil.php# |date = May 2012 }}
=== Urban design === Most fixed houses in northern Tabubil are designed to suit the town and its unique conditions much better than their counterparts in the south, as the 'B' and 'C' class houses are newer. Most of these newer houses have a large dry undercover area under the house, and are raised on stilts. Many people think the houses are on stilts due to the possibility of flooding, but they mostly provide protection from the many [[earthquakes]] in the area.
The entire town is slightly sloped on an increment towards the south. This provides excellent water runoff, which is aided by the many '[[Flood control channel|floodway]]s' which are found around town, and allow large volumes of water to cross roads. Most residents, especially on the escarpment side of town, have large ravines in their backyards which can fill up to a depth of two metres during especially wet periods, and pose a safety hazard.
Because of the large rainfall, there are many indoor sporting facilities in town. Indoor facilities for sports such as squash, indoor cricket, gymnastics, basketball, and other sports are available.
=== The climate and nature === In a country where biodiversity is extreme, the area around Tabubil is regarded as being especially unique. There are untold numbers of different species of birds, fish, insects, spiders, and small animals.  The area around Tabubil is known for moths that grow to the size of dinner plates, bird eating spiders and many other unique creatures.  New species are being discovered constantly.
The sheer abundance of life in the area is attributed to the high rainfall. In town, many plant species, such as [[menta|mint]], that grow elsewhere in the world can be found in large amounts. The plants in Tabubil are larger than usual, and grow much faster than they do elsewhere.
== Economy ==
=== Ok Tedi Mine === {{Main article|Ok Tedi Mine}} [[Image:OkTediMine.jpg|thumb|right|275px|The Ok Tedi mine site]]
Tabubil is the base of operations for the Ok Tedi Copper Mine, the largest economic entity in the Western Province.  The mine accounts for over half of the entire province's economy<ref name=AnnReview/> and 25.7% of the country's entire export earnings.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.oktedi.com/aboutus/ |title = About Us |publisher = Ok Tedi Mining Limited |year = 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070416003426/http://www.oktedi.com/aboutus/ |archivedate = 2007-04-16 |df = }}</ref>  Consequently, Tabubil is the richest and most well served settlement in western Papua New Guinea.
The mine, which operates as [[Ok Tedi Mining Limited]] was formerly owned by a joint initiative between the PNG government, and [[Australia]]n mining giant, [[BHP Billiton|BHP]].  In 2002 the mine was restructured,<ref name=KeyStats>{{cite web | url = http://www.oktedi.com/aboutus/keyStatistics.php | title = Key Statistics | publisher = Ok Tedi Mining Limited | year = 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060820172746/http://www.oktedi.com/aboutus/keyStatistics.php | archivedate = 2006-08-20 | df = }}</ref> and the [[PNG Sustainable Development Program]]<ref name=PNGDSP>{{cite web | url = http://www.pngsdp.com | title =PNG Sustainable Development Program Website| publisher = PNGSDP | year = 2008}}</ref> now owns the BHP share.<ref name=KeyStats/>
=== Town services === Tabubil is serviced by a hotel, a hospital, a police station and courthouse, fire station, two primary schools (one international), a community high school, two supermarkets, a bakery, chemist, two banks, and a hardware store. Various other local businesses create an unusually Westernised culture within this remote town.
Various clubs operate in the town, including the Golf Club, the Hash House Harriers, and the Gazebo club. For non drinking related recreation there is an indoor squash court, indoor cricket centre, tennis courts, a public pool, rugby fields, a gym, and many jungle tracks which may or may not be safe to walk along.
=== Commerce === The main commercial hub of town is in the Centre, to the northeast of the airport. This commercial district is based around a town square plan, and was host to the first [[Automated teller machine|ATM]]s, [[EFTPOS]] machines and public telephones in western Papua New Guinea. The largest store in town, the Tabubil Superstore, is located in the Centre. There is also a smaller, newer supermarket in the north of town and several smaller convenience shops known as ''Lik-Lik Shops'' after the [[Tok Pisin]] word for ''small''.
=== Industry === Tabubil is powered by a hydro-electric station at Ok Menga, capable of producing 10 megawatts of electricity, and has a backup diesel power generating plant.
The main industrial hub is at the south end of the airport. This area was originally known locally as the 'Lay-Down' area, due to the fact that it was the storage location for much of the materials shipped in for the construction of the town. It is currently officially known as the ward of [[Laytown, Papua New Guinea|Laytown]].
A sawmill (now disused) is located at Sawmill Creek.
== Transportation == {{Main article|Transportation in Papua New Guinea}}
Tabubil itself is situated amongst dense jungle on a plateau, beside a steep escarpment leading down to the [[Ok Tedi River]] in the [[Star Mountains]] of [[Papua New Guinea]]. The township is very remote and is only accessible via air, or river barge followed by road.
=== Air travel === Tabubil has an [[Tabubil Airport|international airport]]<ref name=AnnReview>{{cite web | url = http://www.oktedi.com/reports/news/33/2002_Annual_Review_1.7mb.pdf | title = Annual Review | publisher = Ok Tedi Mining Limited | year = 2002 | format = PDF | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070703061845/http://www.oktedi.com/reports/news/33/2002_Annual_Review_1.7mb.pdf | archivedate = 2007-07-03 | df = }}</ref> ([[IATA]] code TBG) with a 1280-metre (4200 ft)<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.aircraft-charter-world.com/airports/oceania/papuanewguinea.htm | title = Airports in Papua New Guinea | publisher = Air Broker Center AB | year = 1998 }}</ref> dirt and gravel airstrip. Most passenger traffic is handled by daily flights to [[Port Moresby]] or [[Mount Hagen]] and tri-weekly flights to [[Cairns]] in [[Australia]] by [[Asia Pacific Airlines (PNG)|Asia Pacific Airlines]] [[Bombardier Dash 8|Dash 8]]s. Prior to the introduction of Dash 8 services, a [[Beechcraft Super King Air|King Air Super 200]] was used for mine traffic.
[[Asia Pacific Airlines (PNG)|Asia Pacific Airlines]] is a local company with head offices in Tabubil, and a good safety record, additionally [[Airlines PNG]], [[Mission Aviation Fellowship]] and [[Air Niugini]] also fly to Tabubil Regularly. Tabubil was also regularly serviced by [[Talair]] before it was disbanded.
==== History ==== In the late 1970s, Tabubil was a small camp. Before construction of the town, Tabubil's first airstrip was in a different location, and a different angle to the airstrip that exists today.<ref name=Higgins>{{cite web |url = http://www.postcourier.com.pg/20020709/supplement04.htm |title = Ok Tedi farewells Dr Higgins |publisher = The Post Courier |year = 2002 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20040819044302/http://www.postcourier.com.pg/20020709/supplement04.htm |archivedate = 2004-08-19 |df = }}</ref> Air travel was instrumental in the development of the town, as there were no roads and the [[Kiunga-Tabubil Highway]], which was a major logistical problem, was not constructed yet.<ref name=Higgins/>
=== Road travel === There are some sealed main streets in Tabubil, and several unsealed minor roads. The central north-south road in the town, separating the 'B' and 'C' houses is called "Spine Road", and is closed to vehicular traffic by large boulders at the end of each local road, apart from a small section at the south that is used for access to a group of townhouses. This non-vehicular road creates a well used and safe walkway through the town. Market stalls are common on this road, and there are two "lik-lik" stores adjacent to the road, and the town's only public park and playground.
All major roads are sealed and contain numerous "floodways" which allow the large amounts of rain in the town to wash over the road without obstructing traffic.
The most common form of roadkill in town is snakes, which will often stretch across the road seeking heat from the bitumen.
==== Kiunga-Tabubil Highway ==== {{Main article|Kiunga-Tabubil Highway}} The township is situated upon an unsealed highway.  One end of the highway terminates at [[Ok Tedi mine]], about 30 km by road to the northwest.  The other end of the highway terminates at the river port of [[Kiunga, Papua New Guinea|Kiunga]], the most northern navigable point of the [[Fly River]],<ref name=QuickFacts/> about 100 km to the south. Buses, private vehicles, and heavy trucking operations run along this route. This highway is used for transportation of supplies to the town and to the mine from barges on the [[Fly River]].  The highway is heavily used by trucking operations heading to and from the port. [[Slurry]] of copper concentrate from the mine is sent to the river port along a 137 km<ref name=QuickFacts/> pipeline which runs parallel to this highway. The [[Kiunga-Tabubil Highway]] is one of the only all-weather roads in the province,<ref name=QuickFacts/> and most other roads in the district feed into this remote highway.
=== River Travel === {{Main article|Kiunga, Papua New Guinea}} Except in cases of severe drought, most supplies to the mine are delivered by barge along the [[Fly River]], which can be accessed by a port in [[Kiunga, Papua New Guinea|Kiunga]] on the southern terminus of the Kiunga-Tabubil Highway. All the produce from the mine and all local exports are sent from this port. The Fly river has a water level which is often too low for shipping, and barges are often banked mid-passage. River barge followed by truck is the only way to supply the township apart from air cargo.
=== Travel by foot === It is not uncommon for residents to access other remote areas by foot.  Most locals can tell you how many days it would take to walk to most locations within the country.  Walking often is the only way for people to get to their local villages anyway, as many local airstrips are in disrepair.<ref name=QuickFacts/>  The maintenance of airstrips is a [[Local-Level Governments of Papua New Guinea|Local Level Government]] responsibility,<ref name=QuickFacts/> and many LLGs in the surrounding area are severely underfunded.
== See also == * [[Ok Tedi River]] The river that runs past the township. * [[Ok Tedi Environmental Disaster]] * [[Kiunga-Tabubil Highway]] * [[North Fly District, Western Province]] * [[Ok Tedi Mine]] The minesite that provides the main economic drive behind the township, and the province itself, operated by [[Ok Tedi Mining Limited]] (OTML). * [[Western Province (Papua New Guinea)]] The remote, impoverished province where Tabubil is located. * [[Kiunga, Papua New Guinea]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}

It was selected as the Kosovan entry for the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]] at the [[91st Academy Awards]].{{cite web |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/oscars-kosovo-selects-marriage-foreign-language-category-1139404 |title=Oscars: Kosovo Selects 'The Marriage' for Foreign-Language Category |last=Holdsworth |first=Nick |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=4 September 2018 |accessdate=4 September 2018}} ==Plot== In the lead-up to Bekim and Anita's wedding, Bekim's friend and former gay lover, Nol, returns from abroad.{{cite web |url=http://enff.nl/film/the-marriage/ |title=The Marriage |last= |first= |publisher=Eastern Neighbours Film Festival |date= |accessdate=4 September 2018}} ==Cast== * [[Alban Ukaj]] as Bekim * [[Adriana Matoshi]] as Anita * [[Genc Salihu]] as Nol ==See also== * [[List of submissions to the 91st Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film]] * [[List of Kosovan submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|6665464|The Marriage}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Marriage, The}} [[Category:2017 films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:2010s LGBT-related films]] [[Category:Kosovan films]] [[Category:Albanian-language films]] [[Category:Gay-related films]] [[Category:LGBT-related drama films]] [[Category:Male bisexuality in film]] {{Kosovo-stub}} {{2010s-drama-film-stub}}
