style="background:#eeaa4e;"| || style="background:#f0df78;"| |||| |- | |} ==Ratification== The twenty-eight European Union-member governments will have to approve of the partnership, via unanimous voting under TFEU Articles 207 and 218, on the negotiated agreement in the [[Council of the European Union]], at which point the [[European Parliament]] will also be asked for its endorsement. The European Parliament is empowered to approve or reject the agreement. In case the [[Council of the European Union]], following a proposal from the [[European Commission]], designates TTIP to be a "mixed agreement", approval from all Parliaments of the EU Member States in accordance with individual constitutional procedures is necessary before the agreement can enter into force. In the United States, both houses of the [[United States Congress|Congress]] will have to pass the agreement for it to be ratified.Ian F. Fergusson, [https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/RL33743.pdf Trade Promotion Authority (TPA) and the Role of Congress in Trade Policy, Congress Research Service ](15 June 2015), p. 9, n.15 ("Under TPA, reciprocal FTAs and multilateral trade agreements that go beyond tariff reductions are treated as congressional-executive agreements, which require the approval of both houses of Congress. Such approval expresses Congress' consent to bind the United States to the commitments of the agreement under international law. This type of agreement is distinguished from both an [[executive agreement]], requiring only presidential action, and a [[treaty]], requiring a two-thirds vote of the Senate. Because reciprocal trade agreements typically result in tariff rate (revenue) changes, the House of Representatives is necessarily involved."). ==Proposed benefits== TTIP aims for a formal agreement that would "liberalize one-third of global trade" and, proponents argue, will create millions of new paid jobs.{{cite journal|last=Bollyky|first=Thomas J. and Anu Bradford|title=Getting to Yes on Transatlantic Trade|journal=Foreign Affairs|date=10 July 2013|url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/139569/thomas-j-bollyky-and-anu-bradford/getting-to-yes-on-transatlantic-trade|accessdate=22 July 2013}} "With tariffs between the United States and the European Union already low, the London-based [[Centre for Economic Policy Research]] estimates that 80 percent of the potential economic gains from the TTIP agreement depend on reducing the conflicts of duplication between EU and US rules on those and other regulatory issues, ranging from food safety to automobile parts." A successful strategy (according to Thomas Bollyky at the [[Council on Foreign Relations]] and Anu Bradford of [[Columbia Law School]]) will focus on business sectors for which transatlantic trade laws and local regulations can often overlap, e.g., pharmaceutical, agricultural, and financial trading. This will ensure that the United States and Europe remain "standard makers, rather than standard takers", in the global economy, subsequently ensuring that producers worldwide continue to gravitate toward joint US-EU standards. In March 2013, an economic assessment by the European [[Centre for Economic Policy Research]] estimates that such a comprehensive agreement would result in GDP growth of 68–119 billion euros for the European Union by 2027 and GDP growth of 50–95 billion euros (about 53.5–101 billion US dollars) in the United States in the same time frame. The 2013 report also estimates that a limited agreement focused only on tariffs would yield EU GDP growth of 24 billion euros by 2027 and growth of 9 billion euros in the United States. If shared equally among the affected people, the most optimistic GDP growth estimates would translate into "additional annual disposable income for a family of four" of "545 euros in the EU" and "655 euros in the US", respectively.{{cite web|url=http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/docs/2013/march/tradoc_150737.pdf|title= Reducing Transatlantic Barriers to Trade and Investment: An Economic Assessment|publisher=Trade.ec.europa.eu|accessdate=2 February 2014}} In a ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' article, the CEO of [[Siemens]] AG (with its workforce located 70% in Europe and 30% in the United States) claimed that the TTIP would strengthen United States and EU global competitiveness by reducing trade barriers, by improving intellectual property protections, and by establishing new international "rules of the road".{{cite news |last=Kaeser |first=Joe |title=Why a US-European trade deal is a win-win |url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702303973704579350783279285204?KEYWORDS=siemens |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |date=2 February 2014}} The [[European Commission]] says that the TTIP would boost the EU's economy by €120 billion, the US economy by €90 billion and the rest of the world by €100 billion. Talks began in July 2013 and reached the third round of negotiations by the end of that year.{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/trade/policy/in-focus/ttip/ |title=Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) – Trade – European Commission |publisher=Ec.europa.eu |date= |accessdate=2014-02-21}} American economist [[Dean Baker]] of the [[Center for Economic and Policy Research]] observed that with conventional trade barriers between the US and the EU already low, the deal would focus on non-conventional barriers, such as overriding national regulations on [[fracking]], [[GMOs]], and finance, but also tightening laws on copyright. He goes on to assert that, with less ambitious projections, the economic benefits per household are unimpressive: "If we apply the projected income gain of 0.21% to the projected median personal income in 2027, it comes to a bit more than $50 a year. That's a little less than 15 cents a day. Don't spend it all in one place".The Guardian (15 July 2013). [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/jul/15/us-trade-deal-with-europe-hype The US-EU trade deal: Don't buy the hype] Retrieved 24 August 2013. A 2018 paper by [[KU Leuven]] economists estimated that a "deep" free-trade agreement, such as TTIP, between the United States and the European Union would increase EU GDP by 1.3% and US GDP by 0.7%.{{Cite web|url=https://voxeu.org/article/free-trade-between-eu-and-us-match-made-heaven|title=Free trade between the EU and US: A match made in heaven|last=Vandenbussche|first=Hylke|last2=Connell|first2=William|date=2018-08-23|website=VoxEU.org|access-date=2018-08-24|last3=Simons|first3=Wouter}} These gains would primarily be the result of reductions in [[Non-tariff barriers to trade|non-tarriff barriers to trade]]. ==Criticism and opposition== [[File:Grossdemonstration gegen TTIP in Berlin Oktober 2015.jpg|thumb|The STOP TTIP CETA demo in Berlin in October 2015 had around 250.000 participants.{{cite web|title=TTIP bringt Rekordzahl von Gegnern auf die Straße|url=http://www.zeit.de/wirtschaft/2015-10/ttip-demonstration-berlin-gabriel-ceta|publisher=ZEIT ONLINE|accessdate=7 August 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Dearden|first1=Nick|title=Think TTIP is a threat to democracy? There's another trade deal that's already signed|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/30/ttip-trade-deal-agreements-ceta-eu-canada|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=7 August 2016|date=30 May 2016}}]] [[File:Cabecera de la mani (17009525818).jpg|thumb|"Stop TTIP" protests in [[Barcelona]], Spain, April 18, 2015]] [[File:2016-04-23 Anti-TTIP-Demonstration in Hannover, (10118).jpg|thumb|Anti-TTIP demonstration in [[Hannover]], Germany, April 23, 2016]] [[File:Stop TTIP-CETA Protest in Brussels 20-09-2016 (15).jpg|thumb|The Stop TTIP-CETA protest in [[Brussels]], Belgium, September 20, 2016]] === Secrecy of content and negotiations === The content of the drafts of agreement, as well as the reports on negotiation rounds, are [[classified information|classified]] from the public, an arrangement that ''[[The Independent]]'' criticised as "secretive and undemocratic". As noted [[#Confidentiality measures|above]], elected representatives may only view the texts in a secure "reading room" in Brussels, to avoid any further leaks of information about TTIP negotiations into the public domain. To answer the criticism, the European Commission has made negotiation documents public, including all EU proposals in the regulatory and rules components of the agreement.{{cite web|url=http://www.euractiv.com/section/trade-society/news/ttip-papers-published-as-eu-ombudsman-demands-more-transparency/|title=TTIP papers published as EU Ombudsman demands more transparency|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/press/index.cfm?id=1230|title=EU negotiating texts in TTIP – Trade – European Commission|publisher=}} The Trade Commissioner has described the negotiations as "the most transparent trade talks ever conducted by the EU".{{cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/commission/2014-2019/malmstrom/blog/ttip-state-play_en|title=TTIP – the State of Play – European Commission – European Commission|first=Joakim|last=LARSSON|date=27 April 2016|publisher=}} === Possible negative impacts === ==== Politics, economy and society==== ''The Guardian'' described TTIP as "the most controversial trade deal the EU has ever negotiated". TTIP negotiations are criticized and opposed by some [[Trade union|unions]], charities, [[Non-governmental organization|NGOs]] and environmentalists, particularly in Europe.{{cite web|author=Leo Cendrowicz |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/04/22/europeans-fight-u-s-trade-deal-with-fear-of-mchospitals-fracking-under-eiffel-tower.html |title=Europeans Fight U.S. Trade Deal With Fear of McHospitals, Fracking Under Eiffel Tower |publisher=The Daily Beast |date= |accessdate=2015-07-14}} ''[[The Independent]]'' summarizes the negative impact of TTIP as "reducing the regulatory barriers to trade for big business, things like food safety law, environmental legislation, banking regulations and the sovereign powers of individual nations",Lee Williams [https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/what-is-ttip-and-six-reasons-why-the-answer-should-scare-you-9779688.html What is TTIP? And six reasons why the answer should scare you]. ''[[The Independent]]''. 6 October 2015. or more critically as an "assault on European and US societies by transnational corporations". German economist [[Max Otte]] stated that the proposed (ISDS) [[Investor-state dispute settlement#Tribunals|court of arbitration and protection of foreign investment]] would mean a "complete dis-empowerment of politics"[https://www.3sat.de/page/?source=/makro/magazin/doks/186138/index.html TTIP: "Völlige Entmachtung der Politik"]. [[3sat]]. Published on 8 April 2016. and that, regarding labour economics, free trade agreements typically enforce lower standards and that TTIP would put European workers into direct competition with Americans (and in effect because of the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] with Mexicans), which would impact European social models. Otte also concluded: "We really don't want the [[social system]] of these countries [United States and Mexico] here [in Europe]." An October 2014 study by Jeronim Capaldo of the [[Global Development and Environment Institute]] at [[Tufts University]] indicates that there will be losses in terms of net exports, net losses in terms of GDP, loss of labour income, job losses, reduction of the labour share, loss of government revenue and higher financial instability among European countries.{{cite web|last1=Capaldo|first1=Jeronim|title=The Trans-Atlantic Trade and Investment Partnership: European Disintegration, Unemployment and Instability|url=http://ase.tufts.edu/gdae/policy_research/TTIP_simulations.html}} ==== Labour standards, workers' rights and job security ==== Anti-poverty group [[Global Justice Now]] asserts that TTIP would undermine job security as well as current minimum labour standards agreed in the EU. [[Labour Party (UK)|British Labour Party]] politician [[John McDonnell (politician)|John McDonnell]], [[Shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer]], has described TTIP as resulting in a huge transfer of powers to Brussels and [[corporatocracy|corporate interests]] that will bring about a form of "modern-day [[serfdom]]". According to a [[European Parliament]] report, impacts on labour conditions range from job gains to job losses, depending on economic model and assumptions used for predictions. In spite of a study by the Munich-based [[Ifo Institute for Economic Research]] (on behalf of the German Federal Ministry of Economics) claiming that up to 400,000 jobs could be created in the EU by TTIP,{{cite web|title=Topical Terms in Economics: Transatlantic Free Trade Agreement|url=https://www.cesifo-group.de/ifoHome/facts/Aktuelles-Stichwort/Topical-Terms-Archive/Transatlantic-Free-Trade-Agreement.html}} Stefan Körzell, national board member of the [[Confederation of German Trade Unions]] (DGB) has said "Whether TTIP can create jobs, and 'how many' and 'where' is unclear. Previous studies, ranging from those conducted by the European Commission across to the expertise of the Ifo Institute, fluctuate between optimism and very low expectations... Consideration of the negative consequences trade agreements can have, if environmental or labour standards are ignored, is often omitted. As of August 2015, the US had ratified two (prohibitions of child labour and slavery) of the eight [[International Labour Organization|ILO]] [[Social clause|core labour standards]]."{{cite web|title=Viavision: The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership|url=http://www.viavision.org.uk/ftp/1887.pdf}} ==== Democracy and national sovereignty, foreign investor protection ==== [[Investor-state dispute settlement]] (ISDS) is an instrument that allows an investor to bring a case directly against the country hosting its investment, without the intervention of the government of the investor's country of origin.{{cite web|author=European Commission |date=3 October 2013|url=http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/docs/2013/october/tradoc_151791.pdf |title=Factsheet on Investor-State Dispute Settlement|accessdate=2014-02-21}} From the late 1980s, certain trade treaties have included provisions for ISDS that allow foreign investors who claim to have been disadvantaged by actions of a signatory state, to sue that state for damages in a [[Arbitral tribunal|tribunal of arbitration]]. More recently such claims have increased in number and value,{{cite web|url=http://unctad.org/en/PublicationsLibrary/webdiaepcb2013d3_en.pdf|format=PDF|title=Recent Developments in Investor-State Disputes|publisher=Unctad.org|accessdate=19 November 2014}} and some states have become increasingly resistant to such clauses.Economist (11 October 2014) [https://www.economist.com/news/finance-and-economics/21623756-governments-are-souring-treaties-protect-foreign-investors-arbitration The arbitration game: Governments are souring on treaties to protect foreign investors] Retrieved 24 April 2015. Critics of TTIP say that "ISDS provisions undermine the power of national governments to act in the interests of their citizens", that "TTIP could even undermine the democratic authority of local government", and that it threatens democracy.Michael Robinson. [https://www.bbc.com/news/business-32116587 Is democracy threatened if companies can sue countries?]. [[BBC News]]. 31 March 2015. France and Germany have said that they want access to investor-state dispute settlement removed from the TTIP treaty.Claire Provost and Matt Kennard. [https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/jun/10/obscure-legal-system-lets-corportations-sue-states-ttip-icsid The obscure legal system that lets corporations sue countries]. [[theguardian.com]]. 10 June 2015 In December 2013, a coalition of over 200 environmentalists, labor unions and consumer advocacy organizations on both sides of the Atlantic sent a letter to the [[Office of the United States Trade Representative|USTR]] and European Commission demanding the investor-state dispute settlement be dropped from the trade talks, claiming that ISDS was "a one-way street by which corporations can challenge government policies, but neither governments nor individuals are granted any comparable rights to hold corporations accountable".{{cite web|last=Stangler |first=Cole |url=http://inthesetimes.com/article/16044/ttip_the_next_corporate_friendly_trade_deal/ |title=The Next Corporate-Friendly Trade Pact |publisher=In These Times |date=30 December 2013 |accessdate=2014-02-21}}{{cite web |url=http://action.sierraclub.org/site/DocServer/TTIP_Investment_Letter_Final.pdf?docID=14701 |title=Letter |publisher=Action.sierraclub.org |accessdate=2014-02-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140224075427/http://action.sierraclub.org/site/DocServer/TTIP_Investment_Letter_Final.pdf?docID=14701 |archivedate=24 February 2014 |df=dmy-all }} Some point out the "potential for abuse" that may be inherent in the trade agreement due to its clauses relating to investor protection.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/sep/14/ttip-deal-british-sovereignty-cameron-ukip-treaty|title=The TTIP deal hands British sovereignty to multinationals|last=Jones|first=Owen|date=14 September 2014|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=Guardian Media|accessdate=5 November 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/business/criticism-grows-over-investor-protections-in-transatlantic-trade-deal-a-945107.html|title= Corporation Carte Blanche: Will US-EU Trade Become Too Free?|last=Schiessl|first=Michaela|date=23 January 2014|work=[[Spiegel International]]|publisher=Spiegel Online|accessdate=5 November 2014}} In December 2013, [[Martti Koskenniemi]], Professor of International Law at the [[University of Helsinki]], warned that the planned foreign investor protection scheme within the treaty, similar to [[World Bank Group]]'s [[International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes]] (ICSID), would endanger the sovereignty of the signatory states by allowing for a small circle of legal experts sitting in a foreign court of arbitration an unprecedented power to interpret and void the signatory states' legislation.{{cite news|url=http://www.hs.fi/sunnuntai/Professori+Suomen+valta+s%C3%A4%C3%A4t%C3%A4%C3%A4+lakeja+voi+vaarantua+/a1386995885773|title=Professori: Suomen valta säätää lakeja voi vaarantua |last=Konttinen|first=Jussi|date=15 December 2013|work=[[Helsingin Sanomat]]|publisher=Sanoma Oyj|language=Finnish|accessdate=16 December 2013}} Faced with such broad and vociferous criticism, ISDS was abandoned in September 2015; in its place, the European Commission proposed an Investment Court System (ICS).{{cite web|title = EU proposes new trade court with US|url = https://euobserver.com/economic/130297|website = EUobserver|access-date = 23 February 2016|last = Nielsen|first = Nikolaj|date = 16 September 2015}}{{cite web|url = http://www.greenpeace.org/eu-unit/Global/eu-unit/reports-briefings/2016/2016_02_11_Greenpeace%20Position%20Paper%20ICS_Final.pdf|title = From ISDS to ICS: A Leopard Can't Change Its Spots|date = 11 February 2016|access-date = 23 February 2016 |page = 1 |publisher = Greenpeace Position Paper |author = Greenpeace}} Not long afterwards, ICS was declared illegal by the German Association of Magistrates,{{cite web|title = TTIP investor court illegal, say German judges|url = https://euobserver.com/economic/132142|website = EUobserver|access-date = 6 February 2016|date = 4 February 2016|last = Nielsen|first = Nikolaj}} though the commission dismissed the magistrates' judgement as based on a misunderstanding.{{cite web|title = EU defends TTIP investor court after German backlash|url = https://euobserver.com/economic/132295|website = EUobserver|access-date = 23 February 2016|date = 17 February 2016|last = Nielsen|first = Nikolaj}} For its part, the United States wants ISDS reinstated. In February 2016, Labour (UK) leader [[Jeremy Corbyn]] said that human rights should be part of TTIP, describing TTIP as a threat to national sovereignty, workers, consumers, health and the environment.[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/ttip-human-rights-workers-corporate-court-law-jeremy-corbyn-david-cameron-pmqs-a6889531.html TTIP 'must include human rights', Jeremy Corbyn tells David Cameron] H. Sheffield, The Independent, 22 February 2016 ==== Public health and environment ==== According to a ''The Guardian'' report, TTIP draft leaked in 2016 shows "irreconcilable" differences between EU and the US in some areas, with the US demanding that EU compromise its "environmental, consumer protection and public health standards".Arthur Neslen. [https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/01/leaked-ttip-documents-cast-doubt-on-eu-us-trade-deal Leaked TTIP documents cast doubt on EU-US trade deal]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. 1 May 2016. ===== Health care ===== {{See also|Healthcare in Europe|Health care in the United States}} [[Trade unions in the United Kingdom|British unions]] such as [[Unite the Union|Unite]] and the [[Trades Union Congress|TUC]] have opposed TTIP on the grounds that it would undermine the [[National Health Service]] and allows for the further [[privatisation]] of public services. A Unite spokesperson described TTIP as "about deregulation and a [[race to the bottom]] on standards. Unison has fought and won on bringing services back into the public sector. ... We cannot allow TTIP to threaten those successes."{{cite news|last1=Chako|first1=Ben|title=TUC says no to TTIP|url=http://www.ukpressonline.co.uk/ukpressonline/getDocument/DWMS_2014_09_11_001?fileType=PDF|accessdate=7 April 2016|work=Morning Star|date=11 September 2014|page=1|format=PDF|subscription=yes}} Former Foreign Secretary [[David Owen]] said that TTIP would have a significant negative impact on the UK's [[National Health Service]] because the Service would be subject to increased competition under the TTIP regime.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/04/06/nhs-would-be-completely-unrecognisable-within-years-if-uk-remain/ NHS would be 'completely unrecognisable' within years if UK remains inside the EU] K. McCann, The Daily Telegraph, 6 April 2016 Former UK prime minister [[David Cameron]] said that critics of [[free-trade]] should not use the [[National Health Service]] (NHS) to take people's attention away, and honestly speak about trade deals. UK's [[Department of Business, Innovation and Skills]] said that TTIP provided adequate protection for UK's NHS.[https://www.rt.com/uk/342384-ttip-deal-nhs-cameron/ ‘Slippery fish’ Cameron is duping the public, TTIP is threat to NHS, critics say] RT, 9 May 2016 Assistant General Secretary of [[Unite the Union|Unite]] [[Gail Cartmail]] said that TTIP was a real and serious threat to the NHS, adding that the threat would not be neutralised unless [[David Cameron]] gave a cast-iron guarantee that he would exclude the NHS from TTIP. ===== Consumer protection and food safety ===== {{See also|European Food Safety Authority|Regulation of genetically modified organisms in the European Union|Pesticide regulation in the United States}} Documents released in May 2015 showed that US negotiators had pressured the EU over proposed pesticide criteria. A number of pesticides containing [[endocrine disrupting chemicals]] were forbidden in draft EU criteria. On 2 May 2013, US negotiators insisted the EU drop the criteria. They stated that a risk-based approach should be taken on regulation. Later the same day [[Catherine Day]] ([[Secretary-General of the European Commission]]) wrote to Karl Falkenberg ([[Directorate-General for the Environment|Director General for the Environment]]) asking for these criteria to be removed.{{r|guardian22may15}} {{As of|2015}}, 82 pesticides used in the US were banned in Europe and US [[animal welfare]] standards are generally lower than those in Europe. A columnist in ''[[The Guardian]]'' stated that [[food safety]] in the EU might be compromised because of low or different standards in US food regulations, if currently EU-banned food were allowed to be imported.Phillip Inman. [https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/oct/18/prospect-ttip-deal-undermining-eu-food-standards-gmos Prospect of TTIP already undermining EU food standards, say campaigners]. [[The Guardian]]. 18 October 2015. In June 2015, the [[BBC]] reported that food safety had become 'a stumbling block' because of differing US and EU attitudes to [[genetically modified crops]], [[pesticides]] ([[Endocrine disruptor|endocrine disrupting chemicals]]), [[growth hormone#Agricultural use|growth promoting hormones]] in beef and [[pathogen]] reduction treatments of [[Chicken (food)|chicken]], that cause public health concerns for consumers and put European farmers at a cost disadvantage.Laurence Peter. [https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-33055665 TTIP talks: Food fights block EU–US trade deal]. [[BBC News]]. 10 June 2015. Ban on [[animal testing]] in the EU has been described by ''The Guardian'' as "irreconcilable" with the US approach. ===== Environment protection and climate change ===== {{See also|Environmental policy of the European Union|Climate change mitigation|Politics of global warming}} A draft of the sustainable development section of TTIP was leaked to ''[[The Guardian]]'' in October 2015. Asked to comment on the document, a French environmental attorney described the proposed environmental safeguards as "virtually non-existent" by comparison with the protection granted to investors, and that environmental cases accounted for 60% of the 127 [[Investor-state dispute settlement|ISDS]] cases already brought against EU countries under bilateral trade agreements in the last two decades, according to [[Friends of the Earth Europe]].{{cite web |last= Nielsen |first= Arthur |date= 23 October 2015 |title= TTIP: EU negotiators appear to break environmental pledge in leaked draft |url= https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/oct/23/ttip-eu-negotiators-appear-to-break-environmental-pledge-in-leaked-draft |website= theguardian.com |accessdate= 23 February 2016 }} According to [[Joseph E. Stiglitz]], TTIP could have a "chilling" effect on regulation and thus "undercut urgently needed action on climate that the Paris agreement requires". He says that industries that do not pay for the "social costs" of pollution in effect receive hidden subsidies, and that TTIP would give companies many more opportunities to sue governments over environmental protection mechanisms.{{cite news | first = Joseph E | last = Stiglitz | author-link = Joseph E. Stiglitz | date = 23 April 2016 | title = TTIP and Climate Change: A Tale of Two Cities from Paris to Hannover | newspaper = [[Süddeutsche Zeitung]] | url = http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/exterior-view-ttip-and-climate-change-a-tale-of-two-cities-from-paris-to-hannover-1.2963133 | access-date = 11 July 2016}} The draft energy chapter of the TTIP was leaked to ''[[The Guardian]]'' in July 2016.{{cite news | first = Arthur | last = Neslen | title = Leaked TTIP energy proposal could 'sabotage' EU climate policy | date = 11 July 2016 | newspaper = [[The Guardian]] | url = https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/jul/11/leaked-ttip-energy-proposal-could-sabotage-eu-climate-policy | access-date = 11 July 2016}} According to ''The Guardian'', this draft could "sabotage" European efforts to implement mandatory energy savings measures and to favor the switch to renewable electricity generation. The draft text obliges the two trade blocs to: "foster industry self-regulation of energy efficiency requirements for goods where such self-regulation is likely to deliver the policy objectives faster or in a less costly manner than mandatory requirements". The draft also mandates that operators of energy networks grant access to gas and electricity "on commercial terms that are reasonable, transparent and non-discriminatory, including as between types of energy". This would open [[feed-in tariff]] schemes to commercial challenge, including [[German Renewable Energy Sources Act|that]] used by Germany. The [[The Greens (Luxembourg)|Green]] [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] [[Claude Turmes]] stated: "These proposals are completely unacceptable. They would sabotage EU legislators' ability to privilege renewables and energy efficiency over unsustainable fossil fuels. This is an attempt to undermine democracy in Europe." The EU's draft text for the trade and sustainable development chapter was also leaked to ''[[The Guardian]]'' in July 2016.{{cite news | first = Arthur | last = Neslen | title = TTIP proposal casts doubt on G20 climate pledge, leaked EU draft shows | date = 13 July 2016 | newspaper = The Guardian | url = https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/jul/13/ttip-proposal-casts-doubt-on-g20-climate-pledge-leaked-eu-draft-shows | access-date = 2016-07-12}} The draft, dated 23 June 2016 and marked "restricted", reveals new loopholes on a [[G20]] pledge to phase out inefficient [[Energy subsidies|fossil fuel subsidies]] by 2025. The [[International Monetary Fund|IMF]] estimates these subsidies run globally at $10{{nbsp}}million per minute{{cite news | first = Damian | last = Carrington | title = Fossil fuels subsidised by $10m a minute, says IMF | date = 18 May 2015 | newspaper = The Guardian | url = https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/may/18/fossil-fuel-companies-getting-10m-a-minute-in-subsidies-says-imf | access-date = 2016-07-12}} and [[G7]] ministers pledged to remove them in May 2016 in a meeting in Japan.{{cite news | first = Karl | last = Mathiesen | title = G7 nations pledge to end fossil fuel subsidies by 2025 | date = 27 May 2016 | newspaper = The Guardian | url = https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/27/g7-nations-pledge-to-end-fossil-fuel-subsidies-by-2025 | access-date = 2016-07-12}} The draft however states that "such a phasing out may take into account security of supply considerations". ''The Guardian'' believes that this passage could be open to abuse and used to slow the phase out of subsidies. ==== Banking regulation ==== {{See also|Bank regulation in the United States}} According to critics, TTIP could weaken the stricter [[bank regulation]]s that are governing banks in the United States as part of the financial reforms that followed the [[financial crisis of 2007–08]].Leala Padmanabhan. [https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-30493297 TTIP: The EU-US trade deal explained]. BBC News. 18 December 2014 ==== Privacy ==== {{See also|Mass surveillance in the United States|Internet censorship in the United States}} Critics of TTIP argue that its proposals on intellectual property could have a similar effect as the EU-rejected [[Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement]] (ACTA). The [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] and its German counterpart, [[Foundation for a Free Information Infrastructure|FFII]], in particular, compared TTIP to the ACTA.{{cite web|work=EFF|url=https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2013/03/transatlantic-declaration-leave-copyright-patent-issues-out-tafta|title=Transatlantic Civil Society Declaration: Leave Copyright and Patent Provisions Out of TAFTA|accessdate= 18 March 2013|date= 18 March 2013|author= Maira Sutton}} === Activism against TTIP === [[File:Stop TTIP Martin Schulz 01.jpg|thumb|"Stop TTIP" [[Civil society campaign|campaigner]]s hand 3,284,289 signatures to [[Martin Schulz]], [[President of the European Parliament]], November 2015.]] In March 2013, a coalition of [[digital rights]] organisations and other groups issued a declaration{{cite web|url=https://www.citizen.org/ip-out-of-tafta|title=IP out of TAFTA|work=citizen.org|accessdate=18 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130320190633/https://www.citizen.org/IP-out-of-TAFTA|archivedate=20 March 2013|df=dmy-all}} in which they called on the negotiating partners to have TTIP "debated in the [[US Congress]], the [[European Parliament]], national parliaments, and other transparent forums" instead of conducting "closed negotiations that give privileged access to corporate insiders", and to leave intellectual property out of the agreement. In 2014, an online consultation conducted by the European Commission{{cite web |url= http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-14-292_en.htm |title= European Commission launches public online consultation on investor protection in TTIP |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= 27 March 2014 |website= |publisher= [[European Commission]] |accessdate= 26 July 2015}} received 150,000 responses. According to the commission, 97% of the responses were pre-defined, negative answers provided by activists.{{cite news |title= EU finds 'huge skepticism' over US trade deal |url= https://news.yahoo.com/eu-finds-huge-scepticism-over-us-trade-deal-203636918.html |date= 13 January 2015 |work=Yahoo News |accessdate=21 January 2015 }} {{cite web|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/wirtschaft/buergerbefragung-zu-ttip-prozent-dagegen-1.2302201|title=Bürgerbefragung zu TTIP: 97 Prozent dagegen|first1=Michael|last1=Bauchmüller|first2=Cerstin |last2=Gammelin|publisher=|via=Sueddeutsche.de}} Additionally, hundreds of demonstrations and protests have taken place in an organised "day of action" on 11 October 2014,{{cite web |url=http://www.stop-ttip-ceta-tisa.eu/ |title=October 11, 2014 – #O11DoA European Day of Action |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= |publisher= |accessdate= 26 July 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://stop-ttip.org/|title=Home – Stop TTIP Stop TTIP|work=Stop TTIP}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/nov/04/british-government-leading-gunpowder-plot-democracy-eu-us-trade|title=The British government is leading a gunpowder plot against democracy|author=George Monbiot|work=the Guardian}} and again on 18 April 2015.{{cite web |url= http://www.euractiv.com/sections/trade-society/thousands-across-europe-protest-against-ttip-313921|title= Thousands across Europe protest against TTIP |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= 20 April 2015|website= euractiv.com|publisher= |accessdate= 27 July 2015}}{{cite web |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=imk56itZc_w|title= TTIP protests 17 18 April 2015 – Lewisham PeopleBeforeProfit|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= |publisher= YouTube|accessdate= 27 July 2015}}{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZLrr0V2a8lE |title=TTIP Aktionstag in Mainz 18 April 2015 |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= |publisher= YouTube|accessdate= 27 July 2015}} In February 2016, Greenpeace activists blocked secret talks on the Investment Court System.{{cite web |title = Greenpeace activists block secret TTIP talks |url = http://www.greenpeace.org/eu-unit/en/News/2016/Greenpeace-activists-block-secret-TTIP-talks/ |website = Greenpeace EU Unit |access-date = 23 February 2016 |date = 22 February 2016}} A self-organised [[European Citizens' Initiative]] against TTIP and [[Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement|CETA]] has also been established, acquiring over 3.2 million signatures within a year. In April 2016, [[Barack Obama]] visited UK, and more than 130,000 people signed a petition organised by political activism group [[38 Degrees]], urging Obama to stop negotiating TTIP. The group planned to send an open letter to Obama to urge Obama to oppose the pact, saying that TTIP would be a threat to [[National Health Service (England)|NHS]], food standards, animal welfare and democracy because it 'gives corporations more power than people'.[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/ttip-more-than-130000-people-urge-barack-obama-to-kill-controversial-trade-deal-during-uk-visit-a6991286.html TTIP: More than 130,000 people urge Barack Obama to kill controversial trade deal during UK visit] R. Revesz, The Independent, 19 April 2016 ==== Leaks ==== In 2016, Greenpeace published 248 pages of classified documents from the TTIP trade negotiations.{{cite web|url=http://www.ttip-leaks.org/|title=Read the secret #TTIP papers here|publisher=}} Greenpeace Netherlands said it released the documents "to provide much needed transparency and trigger an informed debate on the treaty".{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/01/leaked-ttip-documents-cast-doubt-on-eu-us-trade-deal|title=Leaked TTIP documents cast doubt on EU-US trade deal|first=Arthur|last=Neslen|date=1 May 2016|publisher=|via=The Guardian}} ===National objections=== From both the European and American sides of the agreement, there are issues which are seen as essential if an accord is to be reached. According to Leif Johan Eliasson of Saarland University, "For the EU these include greater access to the American public procurement market, retained bans on imports of [[genetically modified organisms]] (GMO) crops and [[Beef hormone controversy|hormone treated beef]], and recognition of [[geographical indications|geographic trademarks on food products]]. For the United States they include greater access for American dairy and other agricultural products (including scientific studies as the only accepted criteria for [[Sanitary and phytosanitary measures and agreements|SPS]] policies)." He observes that measures like the EU ban on hormone treated beef (based as they are on the [[precautionary principle]]) are not considered by the [[World Trade Organization|WTO]] to be based on scientific studies. Eliasson further states that US objectives in a deal include "tariff-free motor vehicle exports," and retained bans on foreign contractors in several areas," including domestic shipping (see [[Merchant Marine Act of 1920]]).Leif Johan Eliasson, [http://jean-monnet-saar.eu/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/10_07_14_TTIP-Eliasson.pdf What is at stake in the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP)? Assessing challenges and possible compromises], Saarland University, 10 July 2014 Already, some American producers are concerned by EU proposals to restrict use of "[[Geographical indications and traditional specialities in the European Union|particular designations]]" (also known as PDO or GI/geographical indications) that the EU considers location-specific, such as [[feta]] and [[Parmesan]] cheeses and possibly [[Budweiser Budvar|Budweiser]] beer.[https://www.economist.com/news/united-states/21607867-europeans-want-their-food-names-back-americans-are-peeved-stressed-are-cheesemakers Food names: Stressed are the cheesemakers: Europeans want their food names back. Americans are peeved], [[The Economist]], 19 July 2014Beer from [[České Budějovice]]/Budweis([[Czech Republic]]) has [[Geographical indications and traditional specialities in the European Union|Protected Geographical Indication]]. [[Budweiser Budvar]] is already [[Budweiser trademark dispute|party to a trademark dispute]] with [[Anheuser-Busch InBev]] over which has the right to use the term. This has provoked debate between European politicians such as [[Renate Künast]] and [[Christian Schmidt (politician)|Christian Schmidt]] over the value of the designations.{{cite web|url=http://www.euractiv.com/sections/trade-society/germans-fret-about-kentucky-fried-bratwurst-under-ttip-311067|title=Germans fret about 'Kentucky Fried Bratwurst' under TTIP|work=EurActiv – EU News & policy debates, across languages}} At French insistence, [[Cultural exception|trade in audio-visual services was excluded]] from the EU negotiating mandate.[http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/html/152670.htm TTIP and Culture], European Commission DG Trade, 16 July 2014 The European side has been pressing for the agreement to include a chapter on the regulation of financial services; but this is being resisted by the American side, which has recently passed the [[Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act|Dodd–Frank Act]] in this field.[http://www.euractiv.com/sections/european-business-summit-2014/eu-us-clash-over-financial-services-ttip-302173 EU-US clash over financial services in TTIP], [[EurActiv]], 15 May 2014 [[United States Ambassador to the European Union|US Ambassador to the European Union]] [[Anthony L. Gardner]] has denied any linkage between the two issues.[http://www.euractiv.com/sections/trade-industry/us-ambassador-eu-anthony-l-gardner-beyond-growth-ttip-must-happen US Ambassador: Beyond growth, TTIP must happen for geostrategic reasons], [[EurActiv]], 16 July 2014 European negotiators are also pressing the United States to loosen [[Energy policy of the United States|its restrictions]] on the export of crude oil and natural gas, to help the EU reduce its dependence on energy from Russia.Zach Carter and Kate Sheppard, [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/05/19/trade-fracking_n_5340420.html Read The Secret Trade Memo Calling For More Fracking and Offshore Drilling], ''Huffington Post'', 19 May 2014
Lidia Pillis, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wonkblog/wp/2014/07/08/could-a-trade-deal-lift-the-u-s-longstanding-ban-on-crude-oil-exports-europe-thinks-so/ A leaked document shows just how much the EU wants a piece of America’s fracking boom], ''Washington Post'', 8 July 2014
David J. Unger, [http://www.csmonitor.com/Environment/Energy-Voices/2014/0715/Europe-at-TTIP-talks-Open-the-US-energy-spigot Europe at TTIP talks: Open the US energy spigot], ''Christian Science Monitor'', 15 July 2014 ===Response to criticism=== [[Karel De Gucht]] responded to criticism in a ''Guardian'' article in December 2013,The Guardian (2 December 2013) [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/dec/02/transatlantic-free-trade-deal-regulation-by-lawyers-eu-us The lies behind this transatlantic trade deal] Retrieved 1 January 2015. saying "The commission has regularly consulted a broad range of civil society organisations in writing and in person, and our most recent meeting had 350 participants from trade unions, NGOs and business" and that "no agreement will become law before it is thoroughly examined and signed off by the European parliament and 29 democratically elected national governments – the US government and 28 in the EU's council"The Guardian (18 December 2013) [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/dec/18/wrong-george-monbiot-nothing-secret-eu-trade-deal You're wrong, George Monbiot – there is nothing secret about this EU trade deal] Retrieved 2 February 2014. However, the [[Corporate Europe Observatory]] (cited in the original ''Guardian'' article) had pointed out, based on a [[Freedom of Information]] request, that "more than 93% of the Commission's meetings with stakeholders during the preparations of the negotiations were with big business". They characterized the industry meetings as "about the EU's preparations of the trade talks", and the civil society consultation as "an information session after the talks were launched".Corporate Europe Observatory (4 September 2013) [http://corporateeurope.org/trade/2013/09/european-commission-preparing-eu-us-trade-talks-119-meetings-industry-lobbyists European Commission preparing for EU-US trade talks] Retrieved 14 April 2015. == Effect on third-party countries == [[File:Transatlantic Free Trade Area.svg|thumb|A possible future Transatlantic Free Trade Area:
the United States and European Union in dark blue and the other possible members in light blue ([[NAFTA]] and [[EFTA]])]] Looking beyond TTIP, a wider "transatlantic free trade area" has been postulated.{{by whom|date=April 2016}}{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} This might include, on the American side, the other members of [[North American Free Trade Area]] (Canada and Mexico); and on the European side, the members of the [[European Free Trade Association]] (Iceland, Norway, Switzerland and Liechtenstein). Mexico already has a free trade agreement with EFTA [[Free Trade Agreement between Mexico and the European Union|and the EU]] while [[Canada–European Free Trade Association Free Trade Agreement|Canada has one with EFTA]] and has [[Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement|negotiated one with the EU]]. These agreements may need to be harmonized with the EU-US agreement and could potentially form a wider free trade area. In early 2013, Canadian media observers had speculated that the launch of TTIP talks put pressure on Canada to secure ratification of its own three-year-long FTA negotiations with the EU by the close of 2013.{{cite news|author=Barrie Mckenna And Bertrand Marotte |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/international-business/potential-us-eu-free-trade-union-puts-the-squeeze-on-canada/article8592389/ |title=Potential US-EU free-trade union 'puts the squeeze' on Canada |publisher=The Globe and Mail |date=13 February 2013 |accessdate=2014-02-21 |location=Toronto}} Countries with customs agreements with the EU, [[European Union–Turkey Customs Union|like Turkey's]], could face the prospect of opening their markets to American goods, without access for their own goods without a separate agreement with the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/transatlantic-alliance-to-cost-turkey-20-billion.aspx?pageID=238&nid=53844&NewsCatID=344 |title=Transatlantic alliance to cost Turkey '$20 billion' – ECONOMICS |publisher=Hurriyetdailynews.com |date=13 September 2011 |accessdate=2014-02-21}} ==Reports== Various groups have produced reports about the proposed agreement, including: * ''The Politics of Transatlantic Trade Negotiations: TTIP in a Globalized World'' (2015) {{ISBN|9781472443649}} * ''The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership: Ambitious but Achievable – A Stakeholder Survey and Three Scenarios'' (April 2013) {{ISBN|978-1-61977-032-4}}{{cite web|title=The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership: Ambitious but Achievable – A Stakeholder Survey and Three Scenarios|url=http://www.bertelsmann-stiftung.de/cps/rde/xbcr/SID-4C33D168-3FA15517/bst/xcms_bst_dms_37655_37656_2.pdf|publisher=[[Atlantic Council]], [[Bertelsmann Foundation]]|accessdate=18 May 2014}} * ''TTIP and the Fifty States: Jobs and Growth from Coast to Coast'' (September 2013) {{ISBN|978-1-61977-038-6}}{{cite web|title=TTIP and the Fifty States: Jobs and Growth from Coast to Coast|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/245085/TTIP_and_the_50_States_GovUK.pdf|publisher=Atlantic Council, Bertelmanns Foundation|accessdate=18 May 2014}} * ''The Transatlantic Colossus: Global Contributions to Broaden the Debate on the EU-US Free Trade Agreement'' (December 2013) {{ISBN|978-3-00-044648-1}}{{cite web|title=The Transatlantic Colossus: Global Contributions to Broaden the Debate on the EU-US Free Trade Agreement|url=http://bfogp.org/publications/the-transatlantic-colossus/|author=Berlin Forum on Global Politics, Internet & Society Collaboratory, FutureChallenges.org|accessdate=3 February 2015}} * ''The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership: A Charter for Deregulation, An Attack on Jobs, An End to Democracy'' (February 2014){{cite web|title=A Charter for Deregulation, An Attack on Jobs, An End to Democracy|url=http://rosalux.gr/sites/default/files/publications/ttip_web.pdf |publisher=Rosa Luxemburg Stiftung, Brussels Office|accessdate=19 November 2014}} ==See also== * [[Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement]] (ACTA) * [[Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement]] (CETA) * [[Copyright infringement]] * [[Digital rights]] * [[European Union free trade agreements]] * [[Investor-state dispute settlement]] * [[Trade in Services Agreement]] (TISA) * [[Trans-Pacific Partnership]] (TPP) * [[Transatlantic Free Trade Area]] * [[United States–European Union relations]] * [[United States free trade agreements]] ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web|title=EU dropped pesticide laws due to US pressure over TTIP, documents reveal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/may/22/eu-dropped-pesticide-laws-due-to-us-pressure-over-ttip-documents-reveal#comments|publisher=Guardian|accessdate=22 May 2015}} {{cite web |last= Jeffries |first= Stuart |date= 3 August 2015 |title= What is TTIP and why should we be angry about it? |url= https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/aug/03/ttip-what-why-angry-transatlantic-trade-investment-partnership-guide |website= theguardian.com |accessdate= 23 February 2016 }} {{cite web|url=https://stop-ttip.org/|title=Do the CETA-CHECK!|publisher=}} Jennifer Rankin. [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/aug/27/cecilia-malmstrom-swedish-politician-play-hardball-with-uk-on-brexit Meet the Swedish politician ready to play hardball with the UK on Brexit]. [[theguardian.com]]. 27 August 2016. }} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [http://www.dw.de/ttip-mega-marriage-facing-hurdles/av-17863865 What exactly is the Trans Atlantic Trade and Investment Partnership?] Video produced by DW ([[Deutsche Welle]]) === Official sites === * [http://ec.europa.eu/trade/policy/countries-and-regions/countries/united-states/ EU negotiations site] * [http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/press/index.cfm?id=1230 EU negotiating texts in TTIP] * [http://ec.europa.eu/trade/policy/in-focus/ttip/ European Commission, DG Trade – In focus Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP)] * [http://www.ustr.gov/TTIP/ USTR Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership] === Discussion and analysis === * [https://www.routledge.com/The-Politics-of-Transatlantic-Trade-Negotiations-TTIP-in-a-Globalized/Morin-Novotna-Ponjaert-Telo/p/book/9781472443649 The Politics of Transatlantic Trade Negotiations], by Jean-Frederic Morin, Tereza Novotna, Frederik Ponjaert and Mario Telò, Routledge, 2015 * [http://epthinktank.eu/2014/07/11/towards-an-eu-us-trade-and-investment-deal-2/ Towards an EU-US trade and investment deal], [[European Parliament]]ary Research Service, 11 July 2014 * [https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld201314/ldselect/ldeucom/179/17902.htm The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership], UK [[House of Lords]] European Union Committee report, 6 May 2014 * [http://bfogp.org/publications/the-transatlantic-colossus/ The Transatlantic Colossus: Global Contributions to Broaden the Debate on the EU-US Free Trade Agreement] ''A collaborative publication with over 20 articles on the global implications of the TAFTA | TTIP'', Berlin Forum on Global Politics, December 2013 * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_iVuEo23LPw The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership – Defensive Move or Constructive Engagement] ''A Research Based Documentary placing the TTIP negotiations in a global context produced by the Institut d'Etudes Européennes of the Université Libre de Bruxelles'', 19 March 2014 * [http://rosalux.gr/sites/default/files/publications/ttip_web.pdf/ The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership: A Charter for Deregulation, an Attack on Jobs, an End to Democracy], Rosa Luxemburg Stiftung, Brussels Office, February 2014 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140819084540/http://www.rosalux-europa.info/userfiles/file/FreeTrade_UHerrmann.pdf / Free Trade: Project of the Powerful], Rosa Luxemburg Stiftung, Brussels Office, May 2014 * [http://katapult-magazin.de/en/artikel/article-katapult/fulltext/politics-at-a-standstill/ / Politics at a standstill], Katapult Magazine, 11. March 2014 * [http://www.cepr.net/documents/TTIP-brief-08-2015.pdf TTIP: Are 40 Cents a Day Big Gains?], [[Center for Economic and Policy Research]], August 2015 === Websites === * [http://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/ttipaction/ TTIP Action] ([[Atlantic Council]]) * [http://ttip2014.eu/ TTIP: What lies beneath] (European Parliament [[The Greens–European Free Alliance|Greens/EFA]] Group) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140321190740/http://www.amchameu.eu/TTIP/tabid/400/Default.aspx TTIP] ([[American Chamber of Commerce to the European Union]]) * [http://www.citizen.org/Page.aspx?pid=6037 The Trans-Atlantic "Free Trade" Agreement (TAFTA)] ([[Public Citizen]]) (USA) * [http://www.businesseurope.eu/Content/Default.asp?PageID=867 Did you say TTIP?] ([[Confederation of European Business]]) * [http://www.nottip.org.uk/ No TTIP] (UK umbrella organisation) * [http://tradeinvest.babinc.org/eu-us-trade/ EU/US Trade & Investment] (British American Business) – backers of the UK [[All Party Parliamentary Group]] for EU-US Trade & Investment * [http://www.ttip-leaks.org/ TTIP Leaks] (TTIP negotiation documents) {{Free trade agreements of the United States}} {{Portal bar|European Union|United States|International relations|Economy}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Transatlantic Trade And Investment Partnership}} [[Category:Economy of North America]] [[Category:Economy of Europe]] [[Category:2013 in the United States]] [[Category:2013 in the European Union]] [[Category:Transatlantic relations]] [[Category:Presidency of Barack Obama]] [[Category:United States–European Union relations]] [[Category:Free trade agreements of the United States]] [[Category:Proposed treaties]]

{{Update|inaccurate=y|date=January 2012}} <!-- Commented out because image was deleted: [[Image:Xmlogo.png|thumb|XM Satellite Radio]] --> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Neural audio logo.gif|thumb|Neural Audio]] -->
On December 28, 2005, [[XM Satellite Radio]] announced that it had teamed up with [[Neural Audio Corporation]] to introduce '''XM HD Surround''', XM HD Surround broadcasts XM channels in 5.1 digital [[surround sound]]. For a time XM broadcast a variety of special shows and live music performances in this format. According to the [https://web.archive.org/web/20051231051818/http://www.xmradio.com/newsroom/screen/pr_2005_12_28.html press release], [[Denon]], [[Onkyo]], [[Pioneer Electronics]] (USA) Inc., and [[Yamaha]] will introduce home audio systems capable of playing XM HD Surround in 2006.
The 5.1 surround sound is encoded in the stereo wave for transmission and is thus compatible with any mono/stereo/matrix-style receiver. If played on a 5.1 audio set equipped with [[Neural Surround]] decoder, the [[watermarks]] (i.e. spatial cues) in the waveforms are detected and the signal is recovered to its original 5.1 form. The technology is similar to [[parametric stereo]], in which a mono signal is recovered to stereo. The [[bitrate]] for XMHD surround broadcasts is ~70 kbit/s using [[aacPlus]] from [[Coding Technologies]].
==XM HD Surround Channels (as of 12/11/08)== * '''XM77 [[Sirius XM Pops]]''' - Classical Popular Music
==External links== * [http://www.xmradio.com XM Satellite Radio] * [http://www.neuralsurround.com Neural Audio] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060502175523/http://www.neuralaudio.com/downloads/NeuralSurroundBackgrounder.pdf Brief description of XM HD Surround technology]
[[Category:XM Satellite Radio]]
